Summary: It's interesting that Indian and Latin American cuisines share some key flavors — tamarind, lime, cumin, chilies, mango — but not interesting enough to sustain at At Vermilion.
Review: [{"Review":"At Vermilion"},{"Review":"480 Lexington Avenue (46th Street), (212) 871-6600."}]
drinks: null

Title: Kottu House
Summary: At Kottu House, Chelaka Gunamuni, a young man in stubbly beard and tattoos (one a birthday gift from his wife), tends to the front of the house while his mother, Sandya “Madu” De Silva, cooks a short menu focused on kottu, a Sri Lankan street food that tosses together tatters of roti, scrambled eggs and long-simmering curry.
Review: [{"Review":"A devil’s face with goggle eyes and swollen tongue stares from the window of Kottu House. It’s only a vinyl decal, meant to evoke the wooden masks — often flanked by cobras, peacocks or flames — that guard the entrances of Sinhalese homes in Sri Lanka, warding off evil."},{"Review":"Inside, the same face is projected above the bar in random glow-stick colors, to the low pulse of trance music."}]
drinks: Seawater fish kottu; crispy prawn kottu; tofu blast kottu; beef rolls; pol sambol; minchi sambol; lunu sambol.

Title: Rôtisserie Georgette
Summary: If Rotisserie Georgette had a clock, its hands would be stopped at five minutes before nouvelle cuisine, when meat was carved to cover the plate and sauce came on the side and nobody turned down potatoes.
Review: [{"Review":"Earlier this year Rôtisserie Georgette put a new chef in charge of its spit-roasted chickens and fish, its fries flecked with tarragon and its baby potatoes heavy with meat drippings, and I couldn’t tell the difference. This is meant as praise, and not the damning-with-faint kind."},{"Review":"The cult of the new in restaurants has brought us many wonders, but it has also left us with the curse of compulsory creativity. It’s no longer enough for chefs to cook hot food that makes us happy; they are supposed to dumbfound us with flavors the human tongue has never tasted."}]
Recommended-dishes: Soaring ceilings, but an intimate Old World feel below. Jackets are not required, though you’d never guess it from the crowd.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Randazzo's Clam Bar
Summary: The dark, concentrated, oregano-accented tomato sauce ladled on hot or chilled lobster, fried shrimp, steamed mussels, scungilli or fried calamari is so central to Randazzo’s mission that some customers never look beyond it.
Review: [{"Review":"The regulars at Randazzo’s Clam Bar know what to order. I was still learning the ropes, though, so I invited suggestions."},{"Review":"My server’s advice was quick and definitive. “Get the calama’,” she said. “That’s why you’re here.”"}]
Recommended-dishes: Suitable for party people on their way to a Russian nightclub, weekend warriors just off a fishing boat and everyone in between.
drinks: Just like home, if you have a big, loud family.

Title: Masha & the Bear
Summary: At Masha and the Bear, the horseradish vodka is infused in-house and stored in pressurized kegs to avoid exposure to air; Anya Vasilenko, the chef, cleaves to tradition with dishes like ukha, a fish soup purportedly beloved by Ivan the Terrible, and Herring in a Fur Coat, a salad born of the Russian Revolution, uniting proletarian herring and peasant potatoes under a mantle of beets in Bolshevik red.
Review: [{"Review":"In the time of Peter the Great, the czar’s chief of police trained a bear to offer visitors a cup of pepper brandy. Down it, and you were ushered in; fail, and you were mauled (or “hugged,” as one 19th-century account delicately put it)."},{"Review":"At Masha & the Bear, which opened in January in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, there is no such entrance fee or ursine enforcer. But a challenge of sorts awaits on the drinks menu: horseradish vodka, infused in house. According to Vitaly Sherman, who runs the restaurant with his wife, Maria (known as Masha), Peter the Great mandated that all Russian inns keep a stash of horseradish vodka in their cellars for the rejuvenation of weary travelers. If an innkeeper did not comply, “he was executed,” Mr. Sherman said."}]
drinks: Blintzes; Olivier salad; solenya (pickles); green borscht; Czar’s ukha (fish soup); beef stroganoff; horseradish vodka; ginger vodka.

Title: Traif
Summary: Thoughtful cooking with subtle and complex flavors on the border of Hasidic Williamsburg and hipsterville.
Review: [{"Review":"IN the valley of the shadow of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, where bearded Hasidim cross paths with mustachioed steam punks, stands the restaurant Traif."},{"Review":"The name, in  Yiddish, refers to food forbidden under Jewish dietary law. To underscore the point, the front door has the logo of a cute little piggy stamped with a heart."}]
drinks: Salad of carrots, oranges, feta, spinach, grapes and sunflower seeds; hamachi carpaccio with nectarines; corn cakes with rock shrimp; duck confit lettuce wraps; cockles with pancetta; scallops with creamed corn.

Title: Reynard
Summary: Nearly everything that comes out of Reynard’s kitchen is chosen by hand and cooked with firewood.
Review: [{"Review":"AMONG summer vegetables, okra is not a heartthrob. If green zebra tomatoes and white nectarines are the romantic leads, the part of okra is a cameo played by Willem Dafoe."},{"Review":"For those wise to its unconventional charms, though, even an okra cameo can be memorable. That was the case the other night at Reynard, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. I was eating an excellent piece of wahoo, which the kitchen treated as something like a cross between swordfish and albacore, grilling it to medium rare and slicing it into generous slabs."}]
Recommended-dishes: A stripped-down brasserie in a soaring industrial space.
drinks: More reasonable than you might imagine, given the tiles, glass and open kitchen.

Title: Cherche Midi
Summary: Cherche Midi may be Keith McNally’s most thorough repudiation of the downtown restaurant scene, and it’s very easy to have a good time, particularly if you stick to red meat and French wine.
Review: [{"Review":"We were halfway through appetizers at Cherche Midi, passing the steak tartare and spreading anchovy toasts with softly jiggly Parmesan custard, when one of my guests suddenly tilted his head and listened. He looked like the boy in a tornado movie who notices that the birds have stopped singing."},{"Review":"“There’s no music,” he said. “They have speakers all over the dining room, but they’re not using them.”"}]
Recommended-dishes: Recognizably a Keith McNally production but softer than usual, this cherry- and apricot-toned bistro is cloistered in a brick bunker.
drinks: Music plays very quietly or not at all.

Title: The Lambs Club
Summary: A clubbish and warm restaurant in the lobby of the Chatwal Hotel that is a kind of Sardi’s for the modern age.
Review: [{"Review":"THERE was a table of fashion people having dinner at the Lambs Club on 44th Street the other night, men and women of letters and soft fabric drinking strawberry gimlets and celebrating lives that allow such pleasures."},{"Review":"An enormous gas fireplace near the table roared away as if in a frontispiece drawing for a 19th-century comedic novel, and though no one could sit or stand before it for long, it was very beautiful. Red leather banquettes stretched far and wide through the black-walled room, beneath old photographs of Broadway and Hollywood legends, original members of the Lambs, a group that gathered until 1973 in this building, now the Chatwal Hotel."}]
address:
132 West 44th Street,
                             Times Square Theatre District
drinks: Conversational.

Title: Violet’s Bake Shoppe
Summary: At this Chinese bakery with a sideline in Vietnamese banh mi, the ratios — of bread to charcuterie (almost all made in-house) to pickles to condiments — are golden. The bread is a cloud in crisp armor, with a crust that snaps like kindling, and then the sandwich is all creaminess, salt and heat, deeply basal flavors and brisk, bright ones, every note seemingly struck at once.
Review: [{"Review":"Some argue that banh mi, the Vietnamese sandwich, lives and dies by its bread, a cloud in crisp armor, preferably made with a pinch of rice flour for extra spring and crackle."},{"Review":"Others keep score by what lies within: layers of fish-sauce-laced charcuterie and musky pâté; cooling strands of pickled daikon and carrots; a jalapeño ambush; a wand of cucumber; sunny cilantro; mayonnaise cut with butter; and a douse of “Vietnamese soy sauce” — typically code for Maggi seasoning."}]
Recommended-dishes: House special banh mi; grilled minced pork banh mi; pork belly banh mi; baked fish banh mi; pâté banh mi; cold noodles; summer rolls; bun rieu cua (crab noodle soup); egg tarts. Prices $2 to $9.75.
drinks: $ (inexpensive)

Title: Maison Premiere
Summary: When Maison Premiere first opened in Williamsburg, it was primarily a bar, serving little more than absinthe and oysters. But now a proper kitchen has been built in the basement and the menu expanded.
Review: [{"Review":"The tight room is astonishingly loud, verging on raucous, but still the waiters murmur, hands behind their backs."},{"Review":"They are better dressed than the diners, in black vests and narrow ties, and never break character. A porcelain cloche is lifted, a sauce poured from a tiny jug, cloche after cloche, jug after jug. At first this prim choreography seems tongue-in-cheek, then earnest, and finally almost silly — and all the more charming for it, like much of the orchestrated seduction that is a night at Maison Premiere."}]
drinks: Sea scallop with pickled rhubarb and horseradish ice; Spanish mackerel escabeche; daurade with tarragon and pickled gooseberries; mussels with saffron potato velouté; turbot; black cod; cannelés and madeleines.

Title: Indian Road Cafe
Summary: Wandering into Indian Road Cafe is like discovering a secret hideaway. In the culinary tug-of-war between innovation and familiarity, the chef Nicholas Wright-Bodine pulls tenaciously for Team Comfort.
Review: [{"Review":"I moved to New York from the West Coast 20 years ago, but only this summer was I introduced to a little-known fact about the island of Manhattan: If you take the A train all the way to its northern terminus, you wind up in Seattle."},{"Review":"Debark at 207th Street and amble in a northwesterly direction, and your steps will carry you to the sort of neighborhood hangout that calls to mind, to be more precise, the city of the Space Needle circa the early ’90s. There’s one counter for some very good coffee, and another with a considered selection of craft beers on tap."}]
drinks: Heirloom tomato salad; grilled octopus; shrimp and bacon sandwich; Maryland crab cakes; skirt steak with roasted potatoes; beer and cocktails; coffee; German chocolate cake.

Title: Empellón Cocina
Summary: Alex Stupak’s mash note to the food of Mexico resembles its inspiration the way dreams resemble life.
Review: [{"Review":"THE danger in writing about the smart and often inspired cooking at Empellón Cocina, Alex Stupak’s free-associating mash note to the food of Mexico, is that other chefs might get the idea that anybody can do what he has done."},{"Review":"Mr. Stupak first took up Mexican food last year, in a Greenwich Village restaurant he called Empellón. He added Taqueria to that first restaurant’s name when he opened Empellón Cocina in the East Village in February. In both cases, Empellón means a push or a shove, as in the push you’d give a child who isn’t sure he is ready to swim. Mr. Stupak is on both ends of that push."}]
Recommended-dishes: Past the half-moon bar is a black-and-white dining room dominated by Sylvia Ji’s eerie paintings and a kitchen window inscribed with the names and ingredients of salsas. Servers may say things like, “It’s kind of a make-your-own-taco kind of deal,” but they do know what they’re talking about.
drinks: Unlike the ones at Empellón Taqueria, the acoustic tiles here do dampen crowd noise.

Title: Indian Accent
Summary: A Midtown branch of an acclaimed restaurant in New Delhi, Indian Accent feeds the desire to see traditional cuisine twisted, bent and played with.
Review: [{"Review":"The emails from New Delhi began last spring."},{"Review":"A new one arrived every few months, informing me that a branch of a restaurant in that city named Indian Accent was about to open in Midtown, and urging me to check it out."}]
Recommended-dishes: An elegantly modern dining room that has character without lapsing into exotic tropes. Servers are personable, outgoing, eager to explain.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Ellary's Greens
Summary: Ellary’s Greens is not so much a restaurant as dining rehab. The menu is devoted to natural and organic foods, and Leith Hill, the owner, is serious about closing the divide between good-for-you and delicious.
Review: [{"Review":"“Free detox shots!” the waitress called out as she sashayed through the dining room, a tray of tiny glasses at her shoulder. The liquid in them was jungle green and wobbled. It tasted of kale and salvation, with celery and lemon for a bright-eyed, bushy-tailed finish. I downed it and waited for the world to change."},{"Review":"Ellary’s Greens, which opened in the West Village in April, is not so much a restaurant as dining rehab. Butter and cream are banned from the kitchen. (A lone stick of butter is stowed behind the counter, a concession to those who require a dab on their morning bagel.) The menu, devoted to natural and organic foods, is minutely annotated to distinguish vegan dishes from the merely vegetarian and to announce freedom from dairy and gluten."}]
drinks: Smoked deviled eggs; crispy roasted chicken breast; grilled salmon; Moroccan lentil salad; black-eyed peas; beets; Brussels sprouts; mashed potatoes; chickpea burger.

Title: Yuba
Summary: Intelligent takes on Japanese cuisine and impeccably fresh sushi.
Review: [{"Review":"Kernels of sunny corn lie cradled in an emerald shiso leaf, tempura-ed whole to a featherlight crunch ($10). Diced maitake mushrooms and taro are hidden among the kernels, so the taste is sweet and earthy at once. There are only three leaves to an order. It is not enough."},{"Review":"How spoiled we are in New York. Elsewhere a place like Yuba would be swooned over, with its intelligent takes on Japanese cuisine and its impeccably fresh sushi. On recent evenings, it was undeservedly empty."}]
drinks: $$$ (expensive)

Title: Le Cirque
Summary: After nearly four decades, Sirio Maccioni still greets each table at Le Cirque, flattering loyal customers and pretending to recognize new ones.
Review: [{"Review":"SIRIO MACCIONI was smiling at the patrons of Le Cirque once again, the way he has done for nearly four decades. He had been scarce over the summer, but on this September night he stopped at every table, fussing over loyal customers and pretending to recognize new ones."},{"Review":"“It’s been a while since you’ve been here, hasn’t it?” he said to a first-timer at my table, guaranteeing that there would be a second meal some day. Asked a question about his health, Mr. Maccioni let his smile cloud over. “They make me work all the time, my sons,” he said, his face a comic pantomime of constant suffering that instantly made clear why he has long been called one of New York’s most charming hosts."}]
Recommended-dishes: Both sedate and a little dotty, with curved walls of polished ebony and a soaring tower populated by statues of monkeys.
drinks: Just loud enough so you know everyone’s awake.

Title: Char No. 4
Summary: The name refers to the burn in a barrel for aging bourbon, one style of more than 150 American whiskeys poured with Southern-accented food in this spot.
Review: [{"Review":"BARS"},{"Review":"Char No. 4"}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: The Gander
Summary: Jesse Schenker, the Gander’s chef, had a breakout hit in 2010 with his debut restaurant, Recette. The Gander is more relaxed in ambition, aiming to be a neighborhood joint.
Review: [{"Review":"They sounded cute, brisket tots, and looked it, dark checkers of meat breaded and crisped, faintly ridiculous in their mini casserole dish. They made me laugh, and then I tasted one. It had the flavor of meat, rich and deep, but the near weightlessness of a doll’s pillow or a dandelion puff."},{"Review":"Now I felt ridiculous. You can’t wax poetic about something called tots; you just say, “That’s crazy good,” and eat."}]
drinks: Buffalo sweetbreads; brisket tots; shrimp toast; lobster roll; calamari salad; sea trout tartare; beet tortelli; spaghetti and clams.

Title: Le Coucou
Summary: At Daniel Rose’s first restaurant in New York, the cooking is informed by old-school traditions, focuses on animal parts, and revolves around glossy, spoon-coating, cream- and butter-reinforced sauces.
Review: [{"Review":"New York City cannot compete with Los Angeles’s patchwork quilt of cuisines, Northern California’s sainted ingredients, New Orleans’s discerning and passionate diners. What sets New York’s restaurant culture apart is that it never quite shakes the past and has never fully severed its ties to Europe."},{"Review":"This is why New York can seem to be stuck in the last century, but it also explains its unusual receptivity to news from across the Atlantic. (No American city has been as fast to take up natural wines or the New Nordic mode.) With Le Coucou, this attention to Europe and attachment to the past come together in ways that are creative and fresh."}]
Recommended-dishes: An elegant loft, with white tapers burning on white tablecloths beneath high ceilings. Service is perceptive, unstarchy, detail-oriented.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Grindhaus
Summary: Aaron Taber, the chef at Grindhaus, makes the kind of earnest, fashionably austere, handsomely arranged food that is signified on menus by sans-serif lists of ingredients, with no capital letters, verbs, articles or hint of how one thing might relate to the next.
Review: [{"Review":"On April Fools’ Day 2008, a former music publicist and retired dominatrix named Erin Norris signed the lease on a derelict Brooklyn storefront where she intended to open a sausage restaurant called Grindhaus. Almost immediately, the universe began sending her a message: don’t."},{"Review":"The space had structural weaknesses, and propping it up would become a long, expensive project. Gas burners would not be an option. Nor would the grinding and stuffing of sausages in bulk; as it turned out, there wasn’t enough room. Ms. Norris ran out of money, raised more, blew through that, scraped up a little extra, spent it on the best kitchen equipment she could afford, and announced that she would open soon. The universe, surmising that the message wasn’t getting through, sent a flood. The night of Hurricane Sandy, water filled the streets of Red Hook and filled Grindhaus, too, wrecking all that kitchen equipment."}]
Recommended-dishes: A tiny dining room with left-of-center artwork that makes it feel more like a cafe or a bar.
address:
275 Van Brunt Street, Brooklyn ,
                             Red Hook
drinks: Low-key but very committed to the job.

Title: Bistro SK
Summary: Bistro SK is an improbably authentic and intimate French bistro in a remote nautical enclave of the Bronx.
Review: [{"Review":"FOR all the restaurants in New York City claiming the name “bistro,” it is rare to find one with the most crucial ingredient. It’s not duck confit; it’s a dining room where everyone is welcomed and waited on by the owner, who may also be (or be married to) the chef."},{"Review":"So it is a shock to find just that in the Bronx, not usually a repository of authentic French cuisine. In fact, since Stephane Kane opened Bistro SK in 2011 with his wife and co-owner, Maria Caruso, he has claimed that it is the only French restaurant in the borough. It is certainly the only one on City Island, an anomalous spit of land that combines elements of a 17th-century fishing village, a working-class beach town and a quiet suburb. City Island is home to fewer than 5,000 New Yorkers, but it is a popular summer destination for day-trippers from the rest of the city. Usually, they come for fried clams and garlic bread — not for French food, except for the fries that families eating outdoors at the Crab Shanty toss up to the predatory sea gulls."}]
drinks: Mussels; escargots in garlic butter; frisée salad; bass with sauce à la Provençale; coq au vin; chocolate mousse with walnuts; floating island; crème brûlée.

Title: Kappo Masa
Summary: The chef Masa Takayama, who owns this restaurant with the art dealer Larry Gagosian, is known for sushi, of course, but Kappo Masa presents a general overview of Japanese cuisine. The cost of eating at Kappo Masa is so brutally, illogically, relentlessly high, and so out of proportion to any pleasure you might get, that the prices become inescapable companions of your meal.
Review: [{"Review":"Galleries owned by Larry Gagosian, the powerful and well-connected dealer who has spent his career goosing the prices of contemporary art higher and higher: 14."},{"Review":"Restaurants owned by the chef Masayoshi Takayama, who has spent his career charging more for Japanese food than anyone else in the United States: five."}]
Recommended-dishes: Casual in spirit with luxurious materials like soft leather seating and teak tables. There are some seats for dining at the bar but none at the sushi station.
drinks: Conversational.

Title: Cassia
Summary: One of the most appealing things about Cassia is its pointed lack of interest in being confrontational. The restaurant goes out of its way to be accommodating, without doing too much violence to the various Asian cuisines (Vietnamese in particular) that inspire much of the menu.
Review: [{"Review":"Editors’ Note: The Times has published starred reviews of restaurants in the New York metropolitan area since 1963. Starting today, we will occasionally offer such reviews of restaurants in other cities as well, applying the same standards that govern our reviews in New York: a minimum of three anonymous visits to the restaurant."},{"Review":"SANTA MONICA, Calif. — On my table at Cassia was a thick, black, gnarled pig tail. The menu said it was grilled, but I was ready to believe it had been incinerated in a rage, as if I had mortally insulted the chef and serving me this stick of carbon were his revenge. But the nice woman waiting on me didn’t seem to think anything was wrong. She seemed excited for me. Would I like her to cut it up, she asked?"}]
Recommended-dishes: A big, open space punctuated by a wood grill, a raw bar and a view of the kitchen. Service goes out of its way to make you feel welcome.
drinks: Vivacious, hitting a crescendo around 8 p.m.

Title: Karu Café
Summary: In this unassuming storefront, two chefs cook side by side, one from Paraguay, the other from Venezuela: harmony between otherwise quarreling nations. Venezuelan arepas, airy corn cakes barely a finger’s width thick, may share the table with Paraguayan chipas, dense, bulging curls of cassava flour and cornmeal fattened by cheese, eggs, milk and butter and tasting like gougères after a gravitational collapse. Karu means “to eat” in Guaraní, the indigenous language written into Paraguay’s Constitution as equal to Spanish, defying the legacy of the conquistadors.
Review: [{"Review":"Two chefs cook side by side at Karu Café, one from Paraguay, the other from Venezuela. Never mind that a continent away, the two nations are hardly on the best of terms."},{"Review":"In August, Paraguay recalled its ambassador to Venezuela and proclaimed a freeze in diplomatic relations. But in an unassuming storefront in the shadow of the elevated train in Woodside, Queens, there is harmony."}]
Recommended-dishes: Empanadas; arepas; sandwich de lomito; mbeju; chipa guazu; chipa. Prices $2 to $25.
drinks: Jugos (fresh juices) and mate (tea); no alcohol.

Title: Houdini Kitchen Laboratory
Summary: Houdini isn’t an of-the-moment speakeasy; it is simply, and wonderfully, a restaurant with good food and earnest intent that just happens to be in one of the coolest spaces in the city.
Review: [{"Review":"To the trophy-hunting diner, the more difficult a restaurant is to find, the more alluring it is. Consider, then, the checklist for Houdini Kitchen Laboratory: No sign. Unmarked entrance at the back of a former brewery. (Better yet, through a fence to the back “yard,” a.k.a. loading dock.) On a bleak block of industrial buildings with graffiti palimpsests and rusted drips from what pass for windows."},{"Review":"Of course, there are now artist studios upstairs, and a free tattoo party may be in swing down the street. But to a first-time visitor, clutching a MetroCard, the scene is desolate. You are 10 stops out of Manhattan on the L line, in the borderland where Bushwick, Brooklyn, blurs into Ridgewood, Queens. (Welcome to Quooklyn.)"}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Hunan Kitchen of Grand Sichuan
Summary: A spare and modern restaurant on Flushing’s Main Street with terrific food, devoted to the cuisine of Hunan province.
drinks: null

Title: Martha
Summary: Martha in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has a homey, built-by-hand back story, and at their best, Andres Valbuena's dishes have the noisy forthrightness of good garage rock.
Review: [{"Review":"Rarely have I been so captivated by gruel."},{"Review":"It appeared as a shallow mush, murky under a yolk sun, at Martha in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. On the menu, it was described as congee, the humble Chinese comfort food in which rice is slow-cooked with excess water to an irresolute texture, neither soup nor porridge. But in layers of richness it rivaled risotto."}]
drinks: Lamb meatballs with congee; brussels sprouts; fluke crudo; egg noodles and duck sausage; broccoli rabe; pear cobbler.

Title: No. 7 Sub
Summary: At this takeout shop, a Manhattan offshoot of the venturesome Brooklyn restaurant No. 7, sandwiches are stuffed with disparate ingredients, with delicious results.
Review: [{"Review":"TYLER KORD may be the Willy Wonka of submarine sandwiches."},{"Review":"At No. 7 Sub, a takeout shop that  opened last month in the Flatiron district, Mr. Kord makes a roast beef hero that tastes of blueberries. He stuffs hoagies with ceviche, and also broccoli. And he piles on candied wasabi, papadams, whole fried lemon slices and doenjang, a Korean fermented soybean paste."}]
drinks: $ (inexpensive)

Title: Izakaya
Summary: An izakaya is an informal Japanese establishment, neither quite restaurant nor tavern, that treats eating as fortification for drinking. But Dai Watanabe, the chef here, is not content to be an accompanist. The mission may be comfort food, but there’s a reverence to its making, even in the minor dishes.
Review: [{"Review":"“We take really good care of the cabbage,” the soft-spoken waiter said, as if that were the only explanation for why the people at my table couldn’t stop eating it, this handful of raw cabbage leaves with little adornment beyond salt, a gloss of sesame oil, dark threads of preserved seaweed and sesame seeds flung on top."},{"Review":"In Japan, he went on, when you go to an izakaya — an informal Japanese establishment, neither quite restaurant nor tavern, that treats eating as fortification for drinking — you order cabbage first, as a test. If the kitchen proves it can pull off such a simple dish, you stay and order more food."}]
Recommended-dishes: Addictive cabbage; cold tofu; simmered kiriboshi daikon; burdock salad; fried potato with pesto mayo; chicken nanban; beef guts stew; hayashi rice; pork curry.
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Locanda Verde
Summary: The chef Andrew Carmellini's cooking at Locanda Verde lacks the polish of his efforts at A Voce, but the best of it makes for a terrific meal.
Review: [{"Review":"RENOWN in the restaurant world can dawn so suddenly and grow so quickly that many chefs get ahead of themselves, winding up a half-dozen paces beyond where they rightfully belong."},{"Review":"For Andrew Carmellini, the opposite has been true. Now 38, he has lagged behind, without billing as prominent or a showcase quite as flattering as he deserves."}]
drinks: $$$ (expensive)

Title: Agnanti
Summary: Agnanti in Bay Ridge, a branch of an Astoria restaurant, offers a welcome take on Greek cuisine: embrace the archipelago.
Review: [{"Review":"IN the popular imagination, Bay Ridge is New York’s Midwest: more conservative, less diverse and distinctly unhip."},{"Review":"But the world at the end of the R train is a far cry from the neighborhood John Travolta strutted through in “Saturday Night Fever.” Italian, Irish, Scandinavian and Greek populations have (somewhat grudgingly) made room for Arab and Asian communities, whose cuisines are a fascinating counterpoint to the diners and old-time Italian joints."}]
drinks: null

Title: Laut
Summary: Hiding behind a pan-Asian menu is some of the best Malaysian food in Manhattan.
Review: [{"Review":"Laut"},{"Review":"15 East 17th Street,"}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Blanca
Summary: Carlo Mirarchi, the chef and owner of Blanca and its sprawling mothership, Roberta’s, is a rigorous miniaturist, combining a few ingredients at a time into two or three-bite compositions that are utterly complete, even if they leave you wanting more; over the years he has steadily refined his marathon tastings, and nearly everything served is remarkable in one way or another.
Review: [{"Review":"When Blanca opened in 2012, a 27-course tasting menu served at a counter behind a pizzeria in Bushwick sounded like the setup to a joke. (Second prize is 30 courses.) The restaurant does have its sense of humor, but it quickly proved that about cooking for maximum pleasure, it was unswervingly serious."},{"Review":"Carlo Mirarchi, the chef and an owner of Blanca and its sprawling mother ship, Roberta’s, was a rigorous miniaturist, combining a few ingredients at a time into two- or three-bite compositions that were utterly complete, even if they left you wanting more. At 31, he already had an impressive sense of what to put on a plate and what to leave off."}]
Recommended-dishes: A very comfortable and relaxed counter where you watch the cooks bend in concentration over course after course. Servers are gracious and unpretentious, with a sense of fun.
drinks: Friendly to conversation, even with Metallica on the turntable.

Title: Cha-An Teahouse
Summary: At Cha-an, up a narrow staircase from the street, afternoon tea is sedate, befitting the simple wooden tables and pewlike banquettes.
drinks: null

Title: The Bronx Beer Hall
Summary: This is a noble effort to coax some youthful energy into one of New York City’s legendary Italian-American neighborhoods. It’s a lovely place to loaf, nibbling on terrifically lip-searing chicken wings and sipping from a well-chilled selection of local brews.
Review: [{"Review":"The chicken wing was juicy and laced with an invisible layer of tempestuous spices, and the moment I bit into it, I turned into Nicolas Cage in “Moonstruck.” Words welled up inside. I needed to tell that chicken wing how I felt: “I’m in love with you.” At that instant, the spices reared back and smacked me across the lips. Delicious agony began to spread to the rest of my mouth. Sips of cold beer did nothing to diminish the impact. Hours later, I could still feel the sting."},{"Review":"I really wanted to adore the Bronx Beer Hall as much as I adored those hot wings, but like Cher’s character, fending off the advances of Mr. Cage’s operatic one-handed baker, the place seemed to specialize in making itself difficult to love. Hatched last year by two young brothers who dream of bringing fresh spirit to a distressingly sleepy stretch of Arthur Avenue, the hall can be found inside an old-school marketplace, where you may pick up a week’s supply of olives, pancetta and marinated anchovies while, if you’re lucky, an elderly gentleman plays an elegiac version of Andrea Bocelli’s “Con Te Partirò” at the lonesome piano by the entrance. Grab a seat at the bar, or at the cluster of tables, and you feel lucky to be surrounded by the bounty of this storied Italian-American neighborhood. You want to linger."}]
drinks: Beer and cider; Grandma Greco’s Special Wings; lizard chips; sweet potato fries; sandwiches from nearby Mike's Deli.

Title: Tavern on the Green
Summary: Compared with its last days before its death of insolvency in 2009 made it the subject of countless dry-eyed eulogies, Tavern on the Green is much, much improved.
Review: [{"Review":"Restaurant critics are supposed to be impartial, but I can’t help feeling some proprietary interest in Tavern on the Green. Not a financial interest, except insofar as a profitable Tavern is good for the city’s budget, which, in a fractions-of-pennies way, is good for me as a grumpy taxpayer. It’s more like a civic interest. Tavern on the Green belongs to the city and sits inside the most beautiful public park in which I’ve ever rowed, cycled, struck out in softball, misidentified a confusing fall warbler and illegally consumed alcoholic beverages. I’d let the city keep those fractional pennies if that helped Tavern on the Green live up to its setting."},{"Review":"So you may detect an extra cup or two of enthusiasm in my voice when I say that under its new management, the building is woven into the life of the park more fully than in its last incarnation, a wedding-cake palace as imagined by a 6-year-old princess with a high fever. And you may hear a few teaspoons of added regret when I say that it’s not a good restaurant yet by any measure."}]
Recommended-dishes: The bar and westernmost dining room are reassuringly dark; the main dining room is numbingly white; the courtyard is a treasure.
address:
Central Park West & 67th Street,
                             Upper West Side
drinks: Poor acoustics in the main dining room can cancel out conversation even when ambient noise is not especially loud.

Title: Caffébene
Summary: The first American outpost of one of South Korea’s largest coffee chains proves that high-quality coffee can be executed on a large scale.
Review: [{"Review":"1611 Broadway (49th Street), (212) 586-2010, thecaffebene.com. "},{"Review":"When it comes to coffee, scaling up usually means bringing in super-automatic espresso machines that grind, dose, tamp and extract coffee with the push of a button. A super-automatic won’t ruin a drink, but it will never make an outstanding cappuccino. At least not until computers learn how to love. "}]
drinks: null

Title: Madangsui
Summary: The best of Manhattan's Korean barbecue restaurants.
drinks: null

Title: Flinders Lane
Summary: There’s a genial ambiculturalism at play at this modern Australian restaurant, which shows clear affection for English tradition while reaching across the Indian Ocean and the South China Sea for more fervent flavors.
Review: [{"Review":"Here is the choice: a bottle of brown HP sauce, with London’s Houses of Parliament in sky blue on the label and a secret recipe (tomatoes, tamarind, dates, molasses, malt vinegar, mysterious spices) dating from the late 19th century, or a ramekin of mayonnaise laced with a house-made sambal of bird’s-eye chiles, fish sauce and palm sugar."},{"Review":"One is a British icon, anointer of the bacon butty, staple of the working man’s cafe. The other is a foundational ingredient in Indonesian and Malaysian cuisine. That they cohabit the same table is testament to the genial ambiculturalism of Flinders Lane, which opened in February in the East Village."}]
drinks: Sausage roll; fluke; pan-roasted squid; tandoori rabbit; chicken san choy bau; grilled lamb rack; steamed snapper; sorbet and ice cream selection; croissant bread pudding.

Title: Giovanni Rana Pastificio & Cucina
Summary: Giovanni Rana Pastificio & Cucina brings fresh pasta dishes to Chelsea Market.
Review: [{"Review":"The basket, made entirely of aged Parmigiano-Reggiano, was pocked and porous like a growth of coral, flaring outward at the rim. Heaped within were snips of asparagus and translucent asparagus-ricotta ravioli, their milky green interiors showing through."},{"Review":"As described by the waiter, the dish had sounded suspect, a flashback to a cornier decade; none of the worldly New Yorkers at my table had wanted to order it. Now they leaned in, eyes bright."}]
drinks: Asparagus-ricotta ravioli; tonnarelli alla Bolognese; maialino; roasted saddle of lamb; ravioli al cioccolato fritti; tiramisù.

Title: Gran Eléctrica
Summary: Gran Eléctrica, an upscale Mexican restaurant near the Dumbo waterfront in Brooklyn, wants to have it both ways: to be elevated yet rustic, chic yet homey.
Review: [{"Review":"THE plastic gloves are handed out discreetly, midmeal, rolled up and tied like transparent diplomas. They are an unexpectedly downmarket accessory for the young and lovely patrons in Gran Eléctrica’s thrumming near dark who glance covertly around the handsome room, carefully affecting nonchalance."},{"Review":"The gloves are intended for the torta ahogada ($13), a sandwich drowned in salsa, a street-food specialty from Guadalajara. Under tentacles of onions, the bread is stained scarlet and dripping. Somehow the crust is still sturdy, but the inside is spongier, closer to mush (in a good way), saturated with the juices of roast pork. It is a crime-scene-spatter pattern in the making, but for those thoughtful gloves."}]
drinks: Aguachile (scallop ceviche); tostada jaiba (crab ceviche); tamal de cambray; tacos with suadero (brisket), carnitas (pork), pescado (fish) and rajas con acelgas (poblanos and chard); pozole verde; churros.

Title: Agern
Summary: Agern feels like a quiet harbor away from the eddies and currents of Grand Central Terminal. In the modern Scandinavian dining room, pale wood, charcoal seat cushions and wall tiles in mossy Grand Central green create a calming mood. Buying food raised around New York, Agern treats the city as another Scandinavian capital: Oslo-on-Hudson.
Review: [{"Review":"Almost everyone who has lived in Manhattan has had the dream. Wandering through your apartment, you see a door nobody has noticed before. On the other side, you find that you have been living all along with extra rooms: enough space for an office, a guest bedroom, a painting studio, a walk-in closet, a tiki bar, a library."},{"Review":"That sensation is what you get walking into Agern for the first time. Just off a corridor in Grand Central Terminal that you’ve probably rushed down hundreds of times, behind a set of doors locked for longer than most New Yorkers can remember, a restaurant has appeared. In the three months since it opened, Agern has made both the train station and the city’s dining landscape into roomier, more interesting places."}]
Recommended-dishes: Inside a busy transit hub, an unhurried oasis in clean, comfortable Scandinavian mode. Servers are attentive and courteous, with almost no stiffness.
drinks: Moderate, and getting more so as the playlists grow less bizarre.

Title: David Burke Kitchen
Summary: A long, brightly lighted, almost-not-awkward space, serving yet another version of the chef David Burke's antic New American fare.
Review: [{"Review":"The James New York, 23 Grand Street (between Avenue of the Americas and Thompson Street), SoHo; (212) 201-9119."},{"Review":"There used to be a great little Ethiopian place, Abyssinia, on Grand Street in SoHo, where you could sit on little stools, swab up fiery chicken stew with sheets of injera and contemplate the essential greatness of New York City."}]
drinks: null

Title: The Musket Room
Summary: At the Musket Room, Matt Lambert, a native of Auckland, prepares New Zealand food that is ambitious and meticulously detailed.
Review: [{"Review":"Twenty years ago, New Zealand cuisine was what the locals call “meat and three veg.” But that is a distant ancestor to what is on the plate tonight at the Musket Room on Elizabeth Street: an archipelago of venison in a licorice jus sea, buffeted by roasted fennel, juniper meringues and celery-root purée."},{"Review":"The chef, Matt Lambert, a native of Auckland, imports all-natural licorice from his home country, a gentle rebuke to Twizzlers. The venison, tender and mild, comes from young red deer raised on a farm north of Wellington by one of his relatives."}]
drinks: Mushroom custard; smoked pork with apple chutney; quail with blackberries; New Zealand red deer with flavors of gin; passion fruit pavlova; pistachio custard.

Title: Colonie
Summary: With a handsome bar in front and a sepia-toned, brick-walled dining room in back, this restaurant serves a mostly solid farm-to-table menu of haute American food.
Review: [{"Review":"THE lack of good restaurants in Brooklyn Heights has been a topic of discussion along the neighborhood’s leafy sidewalks at least since the first white-shoe lawyers crossed the Brooklyn Bridge to settle there."},{"Review":"Residents who run into one another at the Variety Mart on Montague Street speak fondly of Noodle Pudding and Henry’s End, both on Henry Street, or Jack the Horse on Hicks Street, where the liquor store once was. They sing songs to the memory of Bouillabaisse on Atlantic Avenue."}]
Recommended-dishes: A casual look (wood, brick and candles) is complemented by a large wall garden and an open kitchen, as in a farmhouse renovated into a banker’s weekend home.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Nightingale 9
Summary: The chef, Robert Newton — who was born in Arkansas and runs the Southern restaurant Seersucker a few doors down — borrows flavors across a distance, finding resonances between the cooking of Vietnam and that of his heritage.
Review: [{"Review":"The back table at Nightingale 9 overlooks the restaurant’s garden in progress, a patch of broken sidewalk stone with an old bathtub wedged between wooden planters. In the soil, exotic visitors have found a home among the locals: Thai basil, peppery rau ram and frilly perilla mingling with skinny tapers of verbena and heart-shaped lemon balm, which reads as mint to the eye and lemon on the tongue."},{"Review":"On any given night, some assemblage of these herbs will wind up on a plate, tossed with cucumber and lettuces from Brooklyn urban farms and a sifting of crushed peanuts. Dressed in nothing but lime, salt and shallot oil, they taste as if they are still adjusting to life out of the earth."}]
drinks: Vietnamese herb salad, green papaya salad, chilled shrimp and squid, pork shoulder with hand-cut rice sheets, salty lemon-limeade.

Title: Barchetta
Summary: There are encouraging nights when Barchetta seems like the ideal downtown seafood restaurant for people who really love the taste of fish. But when the kitchen loses its rhythm, Barchetta can seem mired among all the also-rans.
Review: [{"Review":"You can count on one hand the chefs in New York who serve bluefish. Narrow the list to those with the confidence to serve it raw, and you’re probably down to one finger and one name: Dave Pasternack."},{"Review":"The challenges of bluefish are formidable. If it isn’t iced right after it’s hooked, if it isn’t killed and chilled properly, if too much time goes by before it arrives at the table, bluefish has a habit of tasting and smelling like discount cat food. Its flavor is strong but its flesh is soft, and when it is raw, a dull, unsteady knife can reduce it to a bruise-colored pulp."}]
Recommended-dishes: Casual and comfortable, although the design hasn’t quite jelled.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Taste of Samarkand
Summary: Don’t be dissuaded by this Uzbek restaurant’s unassuming exterior. Inside is an arbor, with dangling grapes and leaves, and a menu with plenty to please, including improbably airy samsa (meat pastries), soups exhaling dill and kebabs that are hot gulps of salt and smoke.
Review: [{"Review":"The bread looks ready to levitate. Called noni toki, it is matzo-thin, a blistered expanse 14 inches across, the edges uplifted as if in supplication. At Taste of Samarkand, this is achieved by slapping and patting dough around the inverted underbelly of a kazan, a high-sloped Uzbek frying pan akin to a Chinese wok, then baking it over the stove until hard and crisp."},{"Review":"The city of Samarkand, founded in the seventh century B.C. and now part of modern Uzbekistan, was once a stop on the Silk Road for traders bearing spices and culinary traditions from China, Persia and India."}]
drinks: Achichuk; Korean carrot salad; salad Samarkand; samsa; manti; mastava; osh-potche; beef kebab; plov; chicken tabaka; nakhot garmack; lepeshka; noni toki. Prices $1.50 to $15.

Title: Le Bernardin
Summary: No other restaurant in the city makes the simple cooking of fish seem so ripe with opportunities for excitement.
Review: [{"Review":"ERIC RIPERT has been the executive chef of Le Bernardin for 18 years, and people sometimes ask him if he gets tired of cooking fish. Clearly these people have never eaten at Le Bernardin. No other restaurant in the city makes the simple cooking of fish (and the fish at Le Bernardin is cooked simply, when it is cooked at all) seem so ripe with opportunities for excitement."},{"Review":"Some of the thrills are the hushed kind, like the way black garlic, pomegranate and lime support the crisp skin and white flesh of sautéed black bass. Others are scene-stealers, as when a white slab of steamed halibut is slowly surrounded by a crimson pool of beet sauce that, with crème fraîche stirred in, will turn the delirious pink of summer borscht."}]
Recommended-dishes: After a redesign, the monumental dining room feels slightly more intimate and even romantic. The service is always correct, and the servers are a little more likely to break into a smile these days.
drinks: Never rises above a pleasant background murmur.

Title: BK Jani
Summary: Sibte Hassan, the chef and owner of this Pakistani barbecue spot, is a Midas of meat, which he serves at picnic tables on paper plates with no utensils, in homage to the street food of his childhood in Lahore.
Review: [{"Review":"Here comes rack of lamb, fat chops in a ring with the bones jutting off the plate like sun rays. It is luxury, this great wheel of shining meat, crazed with its own juices and tasting of smoke made flesh."},{"Review":"Never mind that it’s served on a paper plate, without a knife or fork. Remember your animal self and what those long bones are for."}]
drinks: Lamb chops; seekh kebabs; burgers; chicken tikka. Prices $3 to $32, cash or Chase QuickPay only.

Title: Mighty Quinn's Barbeque
Summary: Mighty Quinn’s, which slow-cooks high-quality meats using only wood, comes as close to delivering on all fronts as any barbecue place in the city.
Review: [{"Review":"Chase the scent of great barbecue in New York City, and you are rooting for a team that will, sooner or later, let you down. You are a Red Sox fan in any season from 1919 to 2003. There will be enough victories to keep the dream flickering, and there will be nights when you watch the ball hop between the first baseman’s legs."},{"Review":"But every loss feeds a new hope in your heart. This winter, hope came in threes. Barbecue hounds ran to Gowanus to get burnt ends and char siu pork steak at Fletcher’s Brooklyn Barbecue, and to Williamsburg to find out whether BrisketTown deserved to be crowned the Brisket King of New York in a recent cook-off. They descended on the East Village to take apart Flintstonian beef ribs at Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque and watch men in heavy black gloves grab pork shoulder by the fistful and shake it into dripping hunks — yes, real pulled pork on Second Avenue."}]
Recommended-dishes: Plain, with a Chipotle-like quick-service feel, although reclaimed wood tables and stacks of oak, cherry and apple lend some warmth.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Lupulo
Summary: George Mendes’s basic idea for Lupulo was straightforward enough. The place is his take on the beer-centered Portuguese taverns called cervejarias. Much of the menu gets right into the beery spirit, with food that’s left a little rough around the edges.
Review: [{"Review":"If George Mendes did not have such a strong grip on the flavors and aromas of Portugal, Lupulo might have slipped away from him. It can be a confusing restaurant at first, its messages mixed, its fairly simple concept fuzzed over with complications. But give the place a chance, and you can find clarity in the smells of garlic and wood smoke that fill the dining room; in the way sweet paprika and cilantro sidle up to each other in olive oil; and in the fresh, firm seafood, the grilled sardines and carabineros, red as a lobster, their heads dripping with juices that are as rich and intense as any sauce. The restaurant may be unfocused, but the cooking isn’t."},{"Review":"Mr. Mendes’s basic idea for Lupulo, which opened a few blocks south of Herald Square in April, was straightforward enough. The name means “hops,” and the place is his take on the beer-centered Portuguese taverns called cervejarias. The nearest American equivalent is probably a brewpub, which Lupulo resembles with its hard, low wooden chairs, its high ceilings and its U-shaped dining bar stretching off into the distance."}]
Recommended-dishes: An overgrown Portuguese tavern built around a long, U-shaped bar. Servers are welcoming and knowledgeable, if a bit shaky at times.
drinks: Bruising when the room is full.

Title: Olmsted
Summary: Not much about the dining room sets Olmsted apart from any number of other new places to eat. But the quail coop and crayfish tub in the backyard, and the thoughtful, inventive food coming out of the tiny kitchen, tell you that hidden inside this simple and affordable neighborhood restaurant is another, more unusual one waiting to get out.
Review: [{"Review":"Olmsted, a two-month-old restaurant in Brooklyn, looks innocent enough. Not much in the dining room sets it apart from any number of other new places to eat. The houseplants whose vines slink down one wall may well come from Lowe’s."},{"Review":"Toward the back is a cooking space big enough for two people; I believe the term in the trade is “a two-butt kitchen.” The chef, Greg Baxtrom, works on the outside of the pass, putting the last touches on dishes that cost no more than $24."}]
Recommended-dishes: A long, pleasantly unspectacular dining room with a working garden out back for pre-dinner cocktails. Servers are often charming, but the front of the house needs more direction before it hits the kitchen’s level of performance.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Ayada
Summary: A serious Thai restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, that makes no concessions to Western palates.
Review: [{"Review":"I KNEW Ayada was a serious Thai restaurant when I started weeping at my table."},{"Review":"I had just tasted the som tum ($7), a pyramid of shredded green papaya studded with peanuts and doused in a ruthless dressing of raw garlic, fresh lime, dried shrimp, salty nam pla (fish sauce), sugar and a nigh toxic level of bird’s-eye chilies. (These are chilies so potent that the smell of them cooking once set off a terror scare in London.)"}]
drinks: Sour curry with shrimp and broccoli omelet; fried whole fish with basil sauce; crispy catfish with green mango salad; spicy chicken salad; crispy pork with Chinese broccoli.

Title: Alison Eighteen
Summary: Alison Price Becker’s return to Manhattan is a place where civilized adults can have an appetizer and an entree, in that order, and where the kitchen isn’t going to try any funny stuff.
Review: [{"Review":"DID somebody forget to tell Alison Price Becker that in the decade since she last operated a Manhattan restaurant, all of New York below 42nd Street has been taken over by kids, and that their idea of going out to eat resembles some kind of blood sport?"},{"Review":"They have no sense of mortality, these young people. It’s nothing to them if restaurants make them wait all night for a table. They’ll stand up knocking back $16 cocktails for hours as if there won’t be a price to pay in the morning."}]
Recommended-dishes: An American brasserie, with whimsical wallpaper and servers in ties and white jackets. Though nobody asks them to, men tend to wear blazers. Service strives for a relaxed professionalism, with mixed results.
drinks: Well within bounds.

Title: Minetta Tavern
Summary: In freshening up Minetta Tavern, Keith McNally did as expected, figuring out what to buff and what to leave be. But he did something unexpected as well: he fashioned the best steakhouse in the city.
Review: [{"Review":"THE minute you heard that Keith McNally was dusting off  Minetta Tavern — that musty, sputtering Greenwich Village relic from the late 1930s — you probably figured he’d get the look and atmosphere right. This is a project perfectly suited to a restaurateur with a gift for breathing fresh life into familiar genres, for grafting the present onto the past."},{"Review":"You also knew he’d conjure buzz. He always conjures buzz. Where Mr. McNally goes, models, movie honchos and magazine scribes follow, because they’re sure to find themselves among other members of their slavishly fashionable tribe, coddled in an environment that’s as much stage set as mess hall."}]
Recommended-dishes: A cramped late 1930s saloon gets the McNally makeover, which is a respectful combination of period fidelity and contemporary gloss, along with the jostling crowd that usually entails.
drinks: Tiled floor, tin ceiling, hungry throngs: what do you think?

Title: Untitled
Summary: Although the restaurant is on the ground floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art, it is resolutely uninterested in arty food.
Review: [{"Review":"If you can get past the name, a graduate-school groaner that I am supposed to underline, but won’t, there is nothing pretentious about Untitled."},{"Review":"Untitled is on the ground floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art. The Whitney is the second major art museum in the city to choose Danny Meyer to run a big, semiformal restaurant — the Museum of Modern Art is the other — and yet Mr. Meyer is resolutely uninterested in arty food. When Eleven Madison Park began its swerve toward the conceptual, he sold it. The remaining holdings in his Union Square Hospitality Group are polite restaurants where polite people are in very little danger of being challenged or provoked. Although Mr. Meyer has worked to make his name synonymous with hospitality, what his restaurants sell above all is reassurance."}]
Recommended-dishes: An austere glass box on the ground floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art, where nothing distracts from Renzo Piano’s architecture. Service is Danny Meyer Nice®.
drinks: Remarkably low, given all the hard surfaces.

Title: OatMeals
Summary: If the quaint, wholesome scene is expected at OatMeals, the 30-odd variations of oatmeal are not, including bowls — sized in Baby Bear, Mama Bear and Papa Bear, of course — topped with the likes of bacon, truffle oil, coconut milk, sriracha and Gruyère.
Review: [{"Review":"For much of human history, oats were thought of, pityingly, as weeds. The Bible passes over them in silence. The Greeks and Romans snubbed them as a sickly form of wheat. They were fed to horses and, later, to castoff orphans in the workhouses of Victorian England, as grains afloat in murky water, under the name “gruel.”"},{"Review":"A few cultures recognized oats’ worth. The Germans embraced oat porridge, as did the Scots, who developed a special tool for stirring it, a tapered dowel called a spurtle."}]
drinks: Indian spiced; truffle RisOATto; the Canadian; croque monsieur; the Elvis; Almond Joy; strawberry shortcake. Prices $4.25 to $7.25.

Title: Divine Flavored Nigerian Food Truck
Summary: Godshelter Oluwalogbon, the chef behind this Nigerian food truck with bright green hubcaps and a beach scene on its flank, was born in Ghana, his mother’s homeland, and raised in Nigeria, his father’s. On weekdays, he parks in front of the Nigerian Consulate, offering the likes of gizdodo, chicken gizzards folded with caramelized plantains; asun, dark, smoky goat meat sifted with pulverized Scotch bonnets; and ayamase, a chunky stew loaded with beef, tripe and flagrantly rubbery curls of cow skin.
Review: [{"Review":"First, a snack: asun, dark, smoky goat meat sifted with what looks like crimson dust and proves to be Scotch bonnets, smashed into powder and weaponized. This is a fine thing to gnaw on the sidewalk, mouth burning, by a food truck with bright green hubcaps and a beach scene with silhouetted palms on its flank."},{"Review":"In Nigeria, the goat would come with the skin still on. “It has to,” said Godshelter Oluwalogbon, the chef behind the Divine Flavored Nigerian Food Truck, which parks weekdays in front of the Nigerian Consulate, a few blocks east of Grand Central Terminal. But the version he serves here is skinless, he said with a sigh: “For the general public, we have to make accommodations.”"}]
drinks: Yam porridge; honey beans; efo riro; ayamase; meat pie; asun. Prices $3 to $15.

Title: Larb Ubol
Summary: To a passer-by, there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad-Thai joints that are its neighbors in Hell’s Kitchen. But the chef and owner, Ratchanee Sumpatboon, does not cook the Thai food most Americans know.
Review: [{"Review":"To a passer-by, there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad Thai joints that are its neighbors in Hell’s Kitchen."},{"Review":"The dining room is baldly lit, with tables puzzlingly sidelined along the walls, as if the looping Thai pop songs might inspire couples to shimmy across the open floor. A colony of miniature parasols hangs upside down from the ceiling. Banquettes and chair backs are hooded in tartans, a salute not to Scotland but to the traditional checkered pha khao ma cloth used in Thailand as anything from a sarong to a hammock."}]
drinks: null

Title: Buvette
Summary: Chef Jody Williams has poured decades of experience into this all-day West Village spot, where delicious is in the details.
Review: [{"Review":"42 Grove Street (Bleecker Street), West Village; (212) 255-3590; ilovebuvette.com."},{"Review":"A new spot from the peripatetic chef Jody Williams, Buvette is a miniaturized version of a true Paris cafe: easygoing but with just the right patina of formality. "}]
drinks: Anchovy tartine, hazelnut tartine, oxtail marmalade, mussels provençale, beets with horseradish cream, potpie, lamb stew with artichokes, chocolate mousse.

Title: Brad's
Summary: A casual spot for sandwiches, pizza and beer near New York University.
Review: [{"Review":"Opening"},{"Review":"SPASSO Bobby Werhane, an owner of Choptank in Greenwich Village, has taken over the former Alfama space and turned it into a user-friendly Italian restaurant. The mosaic “A” in the sidewalk at the front door is still in place (Mr. Werhane hopes to change it),  but the interior has now been fitted with brown banquettes, a long marble bar and a butcher-block dining bar right at the kitchen. The menu, by Craig Wallen, above, who was at Lupa, starts  with cheeses, meats, fish and vegetable appetizers, then moves on to pastas like garganelli with porcini, and mozzarella cannelloni. Seafood, chicken, rabbit, sausage and steak are among the main dishes, and the house wine is $4 a glass: 551 Hudson Street (Perry Street); (212) 858-3838."}]
drinks: null

Title: Moldova
Summary: At Moldova, devoted to the cooking of the small former Soviet republic, you might feel as if you’d crashed a wedding and been immediately made welcome.
Review: [{"Review":"Branches twine above. Balkan folk-punk pulses below. The mural on the back wall is a postcard writ large, of a cave monastery a millennium old, transplanted from the cliffs along the Dniester River to a utilitarian strip of Midwood, Brooklyn. The tablecloths are red and the chairs hooded in brocade, and every table seems to seat at least eight."},{"Review":"On my visits to Moldova (New York’s one restaurant devoted to the cooking of the small former Soviet republic wedged between Romania and Ukraine), I felt as if I had crashed a wedding and been immediately made welcome. There’s a cheery bravado to the dining room that comes off as charming rather than theme-parky. The details are genuine: The waitresses’ blouses were hand-embroidered in Moldova; the sashes draped on the walls are worn at Moldovan nuptials by “sponsors” who promise to guide the newlyweds through married life."}]
drinks: Veal tongue salad, fried mamaliga balls, fried kashkaval cheese, stuffed peppers, rabbit, grilled beef, stuffed prunes, sour cherry crepes.

Title: Shalom Japan
Summary: Shalom Japan’s unlikely name makes a merry hash of the cultural heritages of the married owners and chefs, Aaron Israel and Sawako Okochi.
Review: [{"Review":"Manischewitz and bubbly is the drink at hand, blushing darkly in a flute glass with a jag of lemon peel. It is a play on a kir royale, with the syrupy Sabbath dinner wine subbing for crème de cassis. It could be a gimmick, but it works: the sparkler, Palmer Brut from Long Island, is fruity and expansive, smoothing over Manischewitz’s neurotic sweetness."},{"Review":"Still, wait for the ba-dum-bump. The cocktail’s name, Oy Vey Iz Kir, tweaks the Yiddish lament “oy vey iz mir”: woe is me."}]
drinks: Sake kasu challah; tuna tataki with black tahini; okonomiyaki with corned lamb tongue; the Jew Egg; New Year’s duck; matzo ball ramen; mochi blintz.

Title: Macao Trading Company
Summary: Macao Trading Co. serves not-quite-Portuguese-Chinese-fusion cooking on two levels: an upstairs devoted principally to dining and a more whimsical lounge where the focus is cocktails.
Review: [{"Review":"TO the question of how a restaurant can season its cooking with an erotic charge, Macao Trading Co. has come up with a laughably unsubtle answer:"},{"Review":"Go with bare breasts, and throw in a dozen or so phalluses for good measure."}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Brooklyn Ball Factory
Summary: A Japanese comfort food and coffee shop in East Williamsburg with a rooftop deck. As for the brief menu, the ingredients are not extraordinary, the preparations not complicated. They don’t need to be.
Review: [{"Review":"The wine is in plastic cups, the view of flaking paint, vinyl siding, a tin tub of flowers and graffiti 10 feet tall. It is so quiet on the roof, for a moment we wonder if the people working the cash register downstairs have forgotten we’re up here and have gone home. None of us are in a hurry to find out."},{"Review":"There are prettier outdoor dining spaces in the city, but few with quite the juxtaposition of serenity and grit as the rooftop at Brooklyn Ball Factory, a Japanese comfort-food joint and coffee shop that opened last fall in East Williamsburg. The single-story building was once a warehouse for beer cans awaiting recycling. Makoto Suzuki, the owner and chef, had the smart idea to take out a skylight and put in a staircase with a glass peak. Climb it at noon and the light stuns; you swell like a hothouse flower."}]
drinks: Grilled pork bento; grilled salmon bento; Japanese curry rice; milky toast; chocolate ganache croissant.

Title: River Cafe
Summary: No place in the city combines spectacle with hideaway intimacy and undiluted romance the way the River Café does.
Review: [{"Review":"Back in the 1960s, when nobody except rats, longshoremen and gangsters needing to dispose of a wayward bookie saw much value in the Brooklyn waterfront, Michael O’Keeffe saw romance. He saw enough flowers for a year of proms, he saw a piano player massaging a Steinway, he saw a curtain of glass framing the Brooklyn Bridge and the lights of Fortress Manhattan on the other side. All of this he saw floating on a barge in the East River. After pleading for permits for 12 years, he persuaded City Hall to see it, too, and in 1977 the River Café dropped anchors."},{"Review":"Did Mr. O’Keeffe see men producing diamond rings from their jacket pockets? He has seen it hundreds of times since. So have I, sitting at the bar one summer a few years back when a young man talked his date into catching the view from the deck outside then dropped to one knee, right next to the swiveling mounted binoculars. I’ll never forget it, or the look in the couple’s dewy eyes when they discovered that the door to the dining room had locked behind them."}]
Recommended-dishes: Flowers, piano love ballads, the skyline: Unless you are wearing a ring or carrying one, be careful whom you bring to the River Café.
drinks: The music, though nonstop, never swamps conversation.

Title: Thirty Acres
Summary: Thirty Acres is the kind of place that can redraw regional boundaries, making the Hudson River no more of a barrier to eaters in search of inventive cooking than the East River has become in the past few years.
Review: [{"Review":"ONE school of criticism holds that chefs should faithfully honor any cuisine they pilfer. But there’s an equally valid case for bold, fearless theft. A good pickpocket does not waste time with introductions."},{"Review":"Respect for Italian tradition would require Kevin Pemoulie to do something different with the remarkably fluffy gnocchi that his kitchen rolls out from starchy potatoes and fresh ricotta. It would suggest, at the very least, a straightforward tomato sauce in the Roman style."}]
drinks: The menu changes too frequently for recommendations to be helpful.

Title: Bar Americain
Summary: The fact that décor and food seem color-coordinated at Bar Americain is a testament to the unsubtle, upbeat spirit of Bobby Flay's cooking.
Review: [{"Review":"152 West 52nd Street, Midtown; (212) 265-9700, baramericain.com."},{"Review":"Monday night in Midtown, Broadway dark and tourists scarce, and a couple walks into Bar Americain to take the measure of the place five years into its run. This is not hard duty."}]
drinks: $$$ (expensive)

Title: The Crabby Shack
Summary: At this airy temple to crab, framed in white and sea blue, there are no whole crabs in buckets, no butcher paper on the tables. But almost everything on the menu is a tribute to the crustacean.
Review: [{"Review":"The sign outside this low-slung storefront no longer says Tabernacle of God’s Glory Church, but the place is still a kind of temple."},{"Review":"Heads bow over plastic bags fogged with steam, cradled in blue gingham paper. Inside may be skinny marionette legs of Alaskan snow crab, looking as if they’re on the verge of tiptoeing off, or plumper Dungeness crab legs, curled inward like fists."}]
drinks: Alaskan snow crab platter; Dungeness crab platter; crab BLT; crab roll; corn bread. Prices $3 to $40.

Title: The NoMad
Summary: The NoMad in the NoMad Hotel is operated by the same duo who run Eleven Madison Park in New York, and with this restaurant, they have done something rather novel and wonderful.
Review: [{"Review":"CREATIVE people should never explain their process to anyone except their biographers, who care, and their spouses, who have to listen. The rest of us ought to be left guessing."},{"Review":"It’s difficult, for instance, to give your full attention to a meal at the NoMad once you have read the interviews in which Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, its ambitious young operators, talk about modeling the restaurant on the Rolling Stones."}]
Recommended-dishes: Fancily if impersonally decorated, like a Riviera home rented out to a rock band.
drinks: Not nearly as loud as a Rolling Stones concert.

Title: Dumpling Galaxy
Summary: Sturdy, knobby, domestic creatures in the Northern Chinese tradition, Helen You's dumplings are stuffed to order, and she fine-tunes them with the sensitivity of a natural cook who really listens to her ingredients. At Dumpling Galaxy, she offers 100 varieties, along with an additional menu of dishes from Hunan, Dongbei and Fujian.
Review: [{"Review":"When I am on my way to a big dinner at a restaurant in Flushing, Queens, I like to limber up by eating a dozen of Helen You’s dumplings."},{"Review":"For the last eight years, Ms. You has been the chef and proprietor of the Tianjin Dumpling House, which is not so much a house as a narrow shaft of elbow room behind a sneeze guard in the basement of a Chinese food-vendors’ market on Main Street. The first dumpling of hers that I tried had a sea-bass stuffing cut with minced ginger, which gave bracing clarity to the few drops of broth sealed inside. It was so satisfying that at first I felt no need to branch out."}]
Recommended-dishes: A bright, modern, comfortable dining room where TV screens show one dumpling after another.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi
Summary: At this barbecue restaurant, the gleaming black grill plate on each table mimics the lid of a traditional Korean cauldron, allowing the pork belly’s drippings to run down into the wreath of bean sprouts, kimchi and garlic cloves snapping on the hot iron below.
Review: [{"Review":"The crowd is of one mind at Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi: From every table rises a gleaming black cast-iron dome with a tapered handle, like the lid of a giant pot, and on every dome lie stripes of pork belly, more white than red, flesh nearly overrun by fat."},{"Review":"The grills are turned high. The room starts to hiss."}]
Recommended-dishes: Pork belly; pork neck; beef belly; naengmyun; bibimbap. Prices $1.99 to $28.99.
drinks: Beer and soju.

Title: Crêpes Canaveral
Summary: At this takeout stand the size of a carnival ticket booth, Jean-Christophe Henry makes Breton crepes from a family recipe that dates back to the late 19th century, and he encourages customers to eat inside the adjacent William Barnacle Tavern, to which Crêpes Canaveral is attached, a low-key, Celtic-leaning bar that was once the taproom of a Prohibition-era speakeasy and still looks it.
Review: [{"Review":"On a drizzly evening, two glum young men peered into the shut window of Crêpes Canaveral. Above them hung a lantern, its candle still unlit. “You really want to go through this for a crepe?” one asked. They tromped off around the corner, but within a minute they had slunk back to wait with the rest of us in the rain."},{"Review":"Crêpes Canaveral, a takeout counter that started serving Breton crepes a few years ago on St. Marks Place, is a one-man operation. And that man — Jean-Christophe Henry, 53, from the northwestern tip of Brittany — is worth waiting for. Every weeknight but Tuesday, he sets up around 6:30 or 7 (on weekends, 3:30 or 4 p.m.), positioning a makeshift wooden marquee with the legend CREPES under the window and laying a plank on top with a hotel-lobby bell affixed. Then he lights the candle and hoists a Breton flag, with its field of ermine spots looking like starred Christmas trees, so faded that its black stripes look almost blue."}]
Recommended-dishes: The complète (egg, ham and cheese crepe); asparagus, egg and cheese crepe; egg, ham, cheese and spinach crepe; butter, lemon and sugar crepe; strawberries, salted caramel and whipped cream crepe.
drinks: Full bar inside the adjacent William Barnacle Tavern with a broad selection of single-malt Scotch from Islay and the Highlands and 20 kinds of absinthe, made in the classic style with an icy fountain drip over flaming sugar cubes.

Title: Leche y Miel Restaurant
Summary: Rideiby Peña, the chef of Leche y Miel, and his wife, Altagracia Peña, both have roots in the Dominican Republic, as do the finest dishes here.
Review: [{"Review":"To begin, mofonguitos: green plantains fried, mashed with garlic and olive oil, then popped into a lemon squeezer, making rough cups that look like craters. Into their maws go knots of hot, plump shrimp and a web, quickly melting, of Parmesan."},{"Review":"At Leche y Miel Restaurant, in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, mofonguitos are gloriously undainty hors d’oeuvres, the plantain base dense but starkly crunchy, the shrimp still preening with heat. They arrive staggered on an angular white plate whose austerity belies the food’s frank pleasures."}]
Recommended-dishes: Mofonguitos; bollitos de yuca; pastelitos; chicharrones de pollo; stewed oxtail; barbecue pulled pork; grilled churrasco; tostones. Prices $4.09 to $27.99.
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Dirt Candy
Summary: Since opening in the East Village in 2008, the chef Amanda Cohen has been waging war on the “eat your vegetables” mind-set.
Review: [{"Review":"DID you hear the one about the rutabaga? No, probably not. Vegetables don’t tend to inspire great jokes. On the contrary, they conjure their very own brand of humorlessness, the tight-lipped officiousness of grim nutritionists that is captured in the phrase “Eat your vegetables.”"},{"Review":"Since opening Dirt Candy in the East Village almost four years ago, the chef Amanda Cohen has been waging war on the “eat your vegetables” mind-set, using humor as one of her weapons. Here she is on her restaurant’s Web site on the subject of cabbage: “It’s the wino of the vegetable world: smelly, unloved and looking at it makes you feel sad. A cabbage salad sounds even worse. Cabbage that’s ... raw? It sounds like a plated suicide note.”"}]
Recommended-dishes: The narrow basement space feels like the dining room on a sleek, architect-designed submarine.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Shake Shack
Summary: Among the most influential restaurants of the past decade, Shake Shack has been studied and copied around the country. But success has also bred a higher class of competition.
Review: [{"Review":"AFTER tossing out one of those limp politician’s jokes about how its arrival in Brooklyn meant that Shake Shack had finally “hit the big time,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg snipped through a green ribbon Dec. 20 to formally open the chain’s location on Fulton Mall."},{"Review":"It is not every day that the mayor serves as midwife at the birth of a hamburger stand, but it is not every hamburger stand that achieves the prominent spot in the city’s consciousness held by Shake Shack. There are 14 of them now, uptown, downtown and out of town (Miami, Washington, Kuwait City). One respectable writer has spoken of the burger as life-changing."}]
Recommended-dishes: Counter service and comfortable indoor seating. Unlike the workers at most fast-food outlets, Shake Shack employees give the impression that they truly like their customers.
drinks: Lively but never overbearing.

Title: Llama Inn
Summary: Llama Inn’s careful kitchen is interpreting the cuisine of Peru, whose vast catalog of ingredients and wild juxtapositions of influences have not been especially well displayed in New York.
Review: [{"Review":"A wedge of light burns in the night on one of Williamsburg’s less picturesque intersections, just below the dark rumble of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Down the block is an old-school Brooklyn-Italian dining room serving linguine, veal parm and clams casino. All around, there’s hipster bait: fried chicken, pedigreed pizza, cans of Narragansett, tacos from a truck in a bar’s backyard."},{"Review":"Behind the windows on this triangular lot, the Llama Inn is something different."}]
Recommended-dishes: Enough windows for a greenhouse and a central bar make this odd triangular corner space feel like a destination. Service doesn’t always make good on its evidently good intentions.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: The Halal Guys
Summary: It started as a nameless food cart on 53rd Street and Avenue of the Americas serving platters of lamb and chicken. Today this business, officially named the Halal Guys, comprises four carts and two restaurants in New York, with franchises set to open around the country and abroad.
Review: [{"Review":"A little over two decades ago, a nameless food cart on the southwestern corner of 53rd Street and Avenue of the Americas started serving platters of lamb and chicken slaughtered in accordance with Islamic law, steeped in Middle Eastern spices and striped with a mysterious and mighty white sauce."},{"Review":"The cart was run by three Egyptian immigrants — Mohamed Abouelenein, from Cairo, and Ahmed Elsaka and Abdelbaset Elsayed, from Alexandria — and open from evening until near dawn."}]
drinks: Lamb over rice; chicken over rice.

Title: Kurumazushi
Summary: Hidden on the second floor of an intensely Ben Katchoresque office building filled with gem dealers, Kurumazushi is one of New York’s oldest sushi restaurants.
Review: [{"Review":"Disco music with raw fish in the East Village may not strike you as a winning formula unless you remember when Avenue A had what was probably the only sushi bar in the city with a mirror ball and a D.J. booth. Everybody called it Disco Sushi, and I loved it for reasons that had nothing to do with the food. I had eaten enough good sushi to know I couldn’t afford it. But cold rice, fake wasabi and sinewy fish mattered much less when vinyl records and the mirror ball were spinning, the tables were filling up with musicians waiting for a 1 a.m. gig at Brownies, and we were all on our third round of sake bombs."},{"Review":"I didn’t realize how much I missed Disco Sushi until I found Sushi Dojo, which opened this summer on First Avenue near East Sixth Street. There were no turntables in sight, but the room was filled with retro disco. Usually, bone-thumping dance music is the way restaurants say “we hate you” to their customers. But at Sushi Dojo the tracks by Chromeo, Sare Havlicek and the like were played at a humane volume and compiled with an evident love for high-sheen, poppy neo-disco."}]
Recommended-dishes: Physically, a classic sushi bar; spiritually, an East Village party.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Prime Meats
Summary: Part of the Frankies empire, this good, very beautiful Germanish restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, has magnetic esthetics: Dutch paint, rubbed wood, old mirrors, brick, warm light out of the past
Review: [{"Review":"THERE are really only two problems with Prime Meats, the very good and very beautiful Germanish restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. The first is that the restaurant accepts no reservations, which can wreak havoc on the evening schedules of visitors who come from beyond walking distance to eat there."},{"Review":"You can see these people standing on Court Street nightly, staring through the plate-glass windows at a dining room packed with brownstone bohemians, third novelists, people with Web sites, with good art at home. They look slightly pained, these visitors from afar wondering about the life choices they made that put them in Chelsea or Park Slope or Montclair, and not down here in Carroll Gardens, this little Italian village off New York Harbor where life is obviously perfect."}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Ardesia
Summary: An unpretentious wine bar with about 30 wines by the glass and a menu of substantial bites, each saltier and tastier than the next.
Review: [{"Review":"Is pedigree destiny? Two sleek new bars from illustrious food families provide clues: Ardesia, descended from Le Bernardin; and Bar Pleiades, from the fecund Daniel Boulud."},{"Review":"Bar Pleiades at Café Boulud, the Surrey Hotel, 20 East 76th Street, Upper East Side, (212) 772-2600, danielnyc.com/cafebouludNY.html, is dark and glamorous —  a fur-lined, lacquered, perfumed cave."}]
drinks: null

Title: The Library at the Public
Summary: There is nothing glib about the food at The Library at the Public, a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled from the upper recesses of the lobby at the Public Theater.
Review: [{"Review":"It is forever after-hours at the Library at the Public, a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled last fall from the upper recesses of the lobby at the newly renovated Public Theater, reachable by a discreetly bland stairwell. (Look to your left.)
