The more likely explanation, it seemed to me, is that the restaurant had to die so New York could live."},{"Review":"As a light beginning to your meal, you could start with a half-dozen fat snails stuffed into the melting marrow of a long shaft of shinbone. After that delicate snack, you could get a little more serious by ordering an entire meatloaf with stroganoff gravy, spaetzle and foie gras. This tower of meat was meant to be shared by four people, but you could round out the meal with slices of buttered brioche weighted down with even more foie gras. That was a side dish."}]
Recommended-dishes: A schoolroom converted to lunchroom; diners eat at desks and read wine lists and menus off chalkboards.
drinks: The acoustics are mysteriously bad; even when the room is half-full, you may have trouble hearing the person next to you.

Title: Chevalier
Summary: There is a lot to enjoy on Shea Gallante's menu at the "brasserie de luxe" Chevalier, but the restaurant is probably not meant for anybody who's in the habit of reading over the check before signing it.
Review: [{"Review":"“What’s the matter?” my dinner companion asked one night at Chevalier, the luxurious new French restaurant in Midtown at the base of the Baccarat Hotel & Residences New York. “You look like you just saw a ghost.”"},{"Review":"Maybe I had. A man wearing an elegantly knotted silk tie had just materialized at our side and wished us “bon appétit” with the ease of a native speaker. He was Charles Masson, who for years steered the stately old ship of La Grenouille until a family struggle sent him out on the streets. He landed at Chevalier as the “director.”"}]
Recommended-dishes: A pretty, muted, softly glowing dining room with Baccarat crystal on every table. Service is excellent; attentive without hovering.
drinks: Quiet but not tomblike.

Title: Cafecito Bogota
Summary: At this Colombian cafe and wine bar, arepas are broad, flat, piled high with toppings and best approached with knife and fork.
Review: [{"Review":"BEYOND Mexico and the Caribbean, another \"New World\" of cuisine still awaits many New Yorkers. These three restaurants offer some surprising flavors from South America."},{"Review":"CAFECITO BOGOTA"}]
drinks: null

Title: La Vie en Szechuan
Summary: The marvel is that the chef, Zhong Qing Wang, a native of Chengdu, manages to refine Sichuan classics without extinguishing them.
Review: [{"Review":"The sidewalk board is scrawled in Chinese, but you are far from Chinatown on East 33rd Street under the needle of the Empire State Building, a block east of signs for live girls and exotic lingerie."},{"Review":"You do not expect to find, past the glass storefront and the yolk-colored banner, gestures toward elegance. But inside, the walls are mounted with carved hardwood fans and shutters. Asymmetrical serving bowls land on white tablecloths. In the evenings, the plain paper napkins of lunch are swapped for ones printed with a single pink rose."}]
drinks: Eggplant with hot green pepper; dan dan noodles; diced rabbit with chile sauce; beer duck; mapo tofu; braised fish filets, Chongqing-style; meatballs with green vegetable soup; golden and silvery buns.

Title: Casa Mono
Summary: Anthony Sasso, the chef de cuisine, has led the Casa Mono kitchen into cooking that a Catalan tapas-bar proprietor might squint at before deciding that tapas do not always need to be interpreted with a strict-constructionist approach.
Review: [{"Review":"Casa Mono has a lot to answer for. Founded by Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich in 2003, it was among the earliest and most influential restaurants to twist the Spanish tapas idiom into what New Yorkers learned to call small-plates dining. The Casa Mono style has spread far and wide, leaving in its wake a trail of cluttered tables, unpredictably sequenced dishes, and diners reduced to asking pathetically, “Will that be enough food?”"},{"Review":"All of this might earn Casa Mono the historical notoriety bestowed on early tremors of annoying or inconvenient trends, like the first spam email, if it weren’t the case that almost everyone agrees that Casa Mono has always been very good. To that I’ll add a contention of my own. The pleasures of eating there are both richer and more varied than in 2004, when this tiny, perpetually crowded restaurant was last reviewed in The New York Times. (Marian Burros gave it two stars.)"}]
Recommended-dishes: A corner bar densely packed with tapas aficionados. Servers are efficient and knowledgeable; sommeliers can be more attentive than food servers.
drinks: Moderately high.

Title: Tempura Matsui
Summary: A serene Japanese cloister serving no-choice kaiseki-style menus.
Review: [{"Review":"After looking over the menu at Tempura Matsui, the woman at the end of the counter made an announcement that would turn out to be catastrophic for her dinner plans."},{"Review":"“I’m allergic to fried food,” she said."}]
Recommended-dishes: Tranquil and traditional, with a tempura counter and three tables under a peaked roof of cypress and bamboo.
drinks: Very agreeable, and even more so if you like the Beatles.

Title: Dosa Garden
Summary: Helping to prove the merits of Staten Island dining, this Southern Indian standout features the deep, smoky, vibrant curries of Chettinad, in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu.
Review: [{"Review":"THERE are plenty of reasons to dine on Staten Island: atmospheric, old-school Italian and German joints; stellar pizza; an intriguing range of Mexican foods; the city’s best Sri Lankan; and, since last year, Dosa Garden, a South Indian restaurant in the Tompkinsville neighborhood, a short cab ride up Victory Boulevard from the ferry terminal. Its talented chef and owner, Karuppiah Chinniah, hails from Chettinad in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, an area known for its intricately spiced dishes, many of them nonvegetarian. Unlike many of the city’s other South Indian menus, half of Dosa Garden’s is dedicated to meat."},{"Review":"The much-loved snacks of Tamil cuisine take up the front of the menu: loose, white patties of steamed rice and lentils called idly ($5); vada, or small dal doughnuts, some dunked in yogurt- or dal-based sauce ($4 to $5.50); and soft, springy utthappam pancakes, including a gorgeous version shot through with red onion and cilantro ($5.50). And there are dosai, like the paper  masala dosa, a chewy, deliciously pungent rice-lentil crepe curled into an enormous, thin roll ($6.50). Most are served with three sauces on the side: a gingery tomato chutney, sweet and salty garlic-coconut chutney, and a terrific sambar. This lentil and vegetable stew can be watery and flat, but Mr. Chiniah’s rendition, fruity with tamarind and amped up with plenty of chilies and black mustard seeds, is rich and deeply flavored."}]
drinks: Kashmiri naan; onion chilli utthappam; paper masala dosa; chicken chettinadu; ennai katherikai.

Title: Bar Bolonat
Summary: The white napkins, polished stemware, sheer curtains and understated modern furniture at Bar Bolonat are all a determined bid for the kinds of diners who would steer clear of anything resembling a hummus hut. Energetic seasoning drives the cuisine, and can be seen in dishes like shrimp in a Yemenite curry, with a fiery shot of green zhug and a small round of fried bread called malawa to soak up the spicy, turmeric-gold coconut milk.
Review: [{"Review":"Some restaurants hit the ground at full tilt. This review concerns one of the others, a place that stumbled at the start, as ungainly as a day-old giraffe, and only recently found its footing."},{"Review":"Bar Bolonat opened in the West Village in March in what seemed an auspicious location, a corner spot looking out on Abingdon Square Park through yards of windows. Two months in, Einat Admony, the chef and owner, was on the verge of closing it, she said in a phone interview. Nearly half of her 54 seats had been taken away after the city ruled that one wing of the dining room was an unpermitted sidewalk enclosure. The disputed area was quarantined behind a velvet rope, although it was hard to imagine a crowd lining up for admission to this patch of bare cement floor. This put a strain on revenues, no doubt, and made the place look pretty weird."}]
Recommended-dishes: An intimate, glassed-in contemporary space that is a bit more polished than the typical bar.
drinks: Moderate to moderately loud.

Title: Tuome
Summary: You have probably eaten in dozens of rooms like Tuome in the past few years, and eaten dishes that look like the ones that the chef, Thomas Chen, is sending from the kitchen. Once the meal begins, though, it becomes clear that Mr. Chen has originality to spare and a clear, fresh point of view, particularly when he interprets Chinese cuisine.
Review: [{"Review":"Look inside the head of a bright young chef and you’ll see a beehive of swarming ideas, a few of them just hatched and others that buzzed in from somewhere else. It can take time to sort out which are borrowed and which have the sting of the new."},{"Review":"Thomas Chen, fresh from the trenches at Eleven Madison Park and Commerce, opened his first restaurant in August, called Tuome. Like so many other places in the era of Noma, it is tastefully spartan in appearance. Its two small dining rooms are furnished with small tables set with small menus printed in small type. The wood chairs and metal bar stools are unsoftened by fabric or cushions. The lights are dim — not flattering, first-date dim but I’m-too-young-to-be-going-blind dim. In terms of glitz and glamour, Tuome falls somewhere between a yoga studio and Thoreau’s cabin."}]
Recommended-dishes: Spartan, brick-lined, dark, with bare wood chairs and bare metal bar stools.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Korchma Taras Bulba
Summary: Sometimes a lot of strong liquor and a little rich food are just the thing, and the Ukrainian fare at Taras Bulba has the combination nailed.
Review: [{"Review":"It starts and ends with vodka."},{"Review":"At Korchma Taras Bulba in SoHo, the first United States outpost of a chain of colorful Ukrainian restaurants, it’s not a question of whether to have a round of shots, only how many and in what flavors. (Cranberry, ginger, horseradish and lemon are the best. Bacon is the worst, by a wide margin.)"}]
drinks: Infused vodkas; salo (salt-cured pork belly); dumplings; holodets; sorrel soup; potato pancakes; pork chop; smetanik; syrniki; honey cake.

Title: Nix
Summary: Liberated from the ideologies of vegetarianism, Nix is free to pursue the hedonic values of vegetables.
Review: [{"Review":"There’s a lot of heavy eye contact going on at this restaurant. One of the most strenuous competitors is a guy at the next table who’s staring down the woman across from him while giving her a ferocious, what-big-teeth-you-have grin. I’d call his expression carnivorous, but we’re at Nix, and there’s nothing to eat here but vegetables."},{"Review":"Not long ago, vegetarian restaurants in the United States were the last place you’d expect to see people who looked as if they couldn’t wait to go home and have non-tantric sex. The mood in their dining rooms could be tranquil, convalescent, earth-motherly, doctrinaire or ascetic, but rarely did it ripple with the energy of hookups in progress."}]
Recommended-dishes: An understated downtown scene, lively but not frantic. Servers are poised, attentive, bright-eyed.
drinks: Moderately loud.

Title: Anjappar
Summary: Chettinadu cuisine, the specialty of this New York franchise of a Chennai-based chain, is surprisingly meat-centric, considering its origins in vegetarian-dominated southern India.
Review: [{"Review":"POONDU KOLAMBU is not a dish to be ordered lightly. Whole garlic cloves mob a turbid brown gravy, the spoils of at least two dismembered bulbs. There is nary a vegetable in sight. It is as if garlic, sick of truckling to other ingredients, staged a coup."},{"Review":"If you subscribe to Ayurvedic philosophy, this is glorious. Those cloves, which liquefy in the mouth like pats of butter, may fend off colds, bellyaches and wrinkles. Still, the dish ($11) is a bold, possibly deranged choice for a first-date dinner (unless you met on Chowhound)."}]
drinks: Poondu kolambu (whole-garlic curry), mutton sukka varuval (braised goat), prawn masala, appam (steamed rice pancake).

Title: Prospect
Summary: As conceived by Annika Loureiro, the pastry chef, desserts at Prospect are an extension, and possibly the fullest realization, of the themes and intent of the preceding meal.
Review: [{"Review":"Here lies a grape, or what was once a grape, before it was rolled in powdered sugar, egg whites and grape juice, then left in a dehydrator until the frosting hardened into a shell and the grape inside deflated, becoming almost a raisin."},{"Review":"This is but one element in a dessert that includes a wedge of pine-nut tart suffused with “blond” chocolate, white chocolate simmered until the milk solids caramelize; a rectangle of candied puff pastry topped with Muscat grape sorbet; a drift of white chocolate powder; and small puff-pastry orbs fattened with white chocolate crème fraîche."}]
drinks: Five-course tasting menu; Wagyu tongue; charred octopus; snow crab “salad”; rack of lamb; panna cotta; chocolate-covered raspberry; pine-nut tart.

Title: Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen
Summary: At Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen, pho chay has a bold near-funk from long-simmering shiitake mushrooms, charred shallots, ginger and a suffusion of spices, and while the broth, as crystalline as consommé, is lovely in its pristine state, it is even better besmirched by brisket that has been smoked for 14 hours.
Review: [{"Review":"Lucky cats beckon from storefronts across East and Southeast Asia, petal-eyed in porcelain, one paw curling up. But I’d never seen one as brazen as this tom wearing shades and cruising on a lotus blossom toward the Williamsburg Bridge. It’s a red swirl of a scene, spray-painted on the wall of Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen, which opened in March in northeastern Bushwick in Brooklyn."},{"Review":"At the top of the brief menu is pho chay, the vegetarian version of pho bo, Vietnamese beef broth noodle soup. Often pho chay is mild and self-effacing, perhaps in keeping with its Buddhist origins. Here it has a bold near funk from long-simmering shiitake mushrooms, charred shallots, ginger and a suffusion of star anise, cardamom, cinnamon, cloves and fennel."}]
drinks: Pho with smoked brisket, chicken or tofu; pho banh mi. Prices $8 to $12.

Title: Onomea
Summary: Spam gets pride of place at Onomea, which serves Hawaiian food in a dining room that suggests a sauna in the middle of a rain forest.
Review: [{"Review":"When the Spam arrived, a prefab-pink stripe embedded in a triangle of rice trussed with nori, I turned to my dubious companions and said, “This will be the best thing we eat tonight.”"},{"Review":"There is nothing ironic about Spam at Onomea (pronounced oh-no-MAY-ah), a Hawaiian restaurant that opened in August in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Some seven million tins of the pork-and-ham-based luncheon meat are consumed in Hawaii each year. Local McDonald’s serve it; street festivals celebrate it."}]
drinks: Spam musubi; loco moco; kalua pig; Spam fried rice.

Title: Fowler & Wells
Summary: Tom Colicchio, the chef and owner, tries to bring some Gilded Age exuberance to this restaurant in a restored 1883 building. Many of the components, including the cocktails, wine list and desserts, are excellent. But in the menu and the décor, the central vision is fuzzy, and the restaurant is somehow less than the sum of its parts.
Review: [{"Review":"You enter Tom Colicchio’s new restaurant near City Hall through what is suddenly the most stunning hotel lobby bar in New York City. The Beekman hotel’s bar is at the bottom of the atrium of the 1883 Temple Court Building, which rises up through seven floors of elaborate cast-iron railings to end in a soaring glass pyramid. It’s a striking room where you can sink into an armchair with a solidly built drink in your hand and get lost in the past, a quintessentially urban experience that most of the city’s grand old hotels no longer give us."},{"Review":"With Fowler & Wells, Mr. Colicchio tries to extend the atrium’s Gilded Age exuberance. He never quite gets there. The problem isn’t quality or effort: The cooking is spotlessly correct, the ingredients shimmer on the plate, the flavors all make sense, and the dining room is dignified in a way that makes you realize how undervalued that trait has become in restaurants. But the central vision tying it all together is fuzzy. The restaurant is somehow less than the sum of its parts."}]
Recommended-dishes: A dramatic dining room that combines modern style with elaborate vintage elements. It’s almost steampunk, but not quite. Servers are attentive and quick to respond, with a slightly formal reserve.
drinks: Moderate. Conversation is easy despite the background music.

Title: Chomp Chomp
Summary: Like going from hawker stall to hawker stall without leaving your seat.
Review: [{"Review":"“Whenever I find myself growing grim about the mouth, whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul,” Herman Melville wrote, “I account it high time to get to sea as soon as I can.”"},{"Review":"I feel you, Herman."}]
Recommended-dishes: Soft lighting and Chinese antiques dress up a small, simple room.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Dhaulagiri Kitchen
Summary: Dhaulagiri Kitchen, whose name appears nowhere outside this shack of a storefront, shares a cramped, chaotic space with a chapati bakery. The disheveled setting is part of the charm.
Review: [{"Review":"“You won’t like it,” we are warned."},{"Review":"Nevertheless, the chef and owner of Dhaulagiri Kitchen, Kamala Gauchan, brings the dish to our table: dhedo, a brownish-gray mass of what looks like unbaked bread, slapped down on a round metal plate and circled by small bowls of curry and bright dabs of Nepali pickles."}]
drinks: Aloo dum; chana chatpate; sandheko waiwai; sukuti; thali.

Title: The Tangled Vine
Summary: An excellent wine bar on the Upper West Side serving Mediterranean fare.
Review: [{"Review":" 434 Amsterdam Avenue (81st Street), Upper West Side; (646) 863-3896, tangledvinebar.com."},{"Review":"By any measure, this  is a welcome addition to New York’s thriving community of wine bars. But by the special calculus required to assess restaurants on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the Tangled Vine is manna from heaven."}]
drinks: null

Title: Five Leaves
Summary: Five Leaves in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, serves simple Australian food with a bit of flair and modest prices.
Review: [{"Review":"BEFORE asking the waiter at Five Leaves about a drink on the cocktail list, the Whiskey in a Jar ($9), I had to ask about his tattoos."},{"Review":"They were that striking. On one arm was a silhouette of an elk; on the other a water tower, the kind that dots the low-slung skyline of Greenpoint, the neighborhood Five Leaves calls home. “My friend came up with this in, like, five minutes,” he said proudly. “It’s my tribute to Brooklyn.”"}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: San Matteo Pizza and Espresso Bar
Summary: A tiny spot with a roaring oven that produces outstanding Neapolitan pizzas and panuozzi sandwiches
Review: [{"Review":"1739 Second Avenue (90th Street), (212) 426-6943."},{"Review":"The brick oven bulges through a wall, a hot obstruction on the way to the restroom. Shuffling pies takes an acrobat. The peel seems half as long as the restaurant, about as wide."}]
drinks: null

Title: DeFonte's of Brooklyn
Summary: After 87 years, this Red Hook, Brooklyn, institution for super-sized subs has opened a branch in Manhattan.
Review: [{"Review":"NANCY AND AZIZ LAMAZOU hail from Lebanon and Tunisia. During Mr. Lamazou’s years as a diplomat, they ate their way across the globe. They’re purveyors of fine European packaged goods. They cave continental cheeses beneath a New York City sidewalk. They sell carefully made sandwiches."},{"Review":"Nicky Defonte, born and raised in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the kind of guy who says “New York” and means Manhattan, as in: “Brooklyn is a great spot, don’t get me wrong, but New York is where you get the recognition. And I always wanted to come to New York.” He buys his bread from “Joe in Coney Island.” He, too, sells carefully made sandwiches."}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Asian Spicy Curry
Summary: Yip Khuan Thye, a native of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, takes over the kitchen of Mama Eatery in Chinatown; the curries on the nocturnal pop-up menu are priced at $6 or $7, each a small world.
Review: [{"Review":"Chinatown grows quiet here at night, near the southern end of Mulberry Street. Mama Eatery stands where Mulberry bends, between a funeral-supply shop and a dry cleaner. There are Chinese characters on the window, but the menu knows no borders: lox and French toast for breakfast, pierogies, paninis and linguine pomodoro for jury-duty lunch, bubble tea for kids just freed from school."},{"Review":"Come dark, the dining room dims and the TV goes black. Butcher paper is neatly clipped over the metal tabletops. Votive candles start brooding. The quick set change signals the arrival of a new chef in the kitchen, Yip Khuan Thye, a native of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, bearing curry leaves and candlenuts."}]
drinks: Curry noodle soup with eggplant and tofu stuffed with fish paste; curry noodle soup with seafood; curry chicken; curry beef. Prices $6 to $7.

Title: Khao Kang
Summary: At Khao Kang, there is no menu or wait service. Food is premade and presented cafeteria style.
Review: [{"Review":"If you ask, the patient people at Khao Kang will identify the dozen unlabeled dishes on the steam table for you, but this will not necessarily help. Their one-word descriptions (“shrimp,” “chicken” and, repeatedly, “pork”) tell nothing of the layers of flavor, surprises and comforts to be found here, in one of the sincerest Thai restaurants in New York City."},{"Review":"Perhaps “restaurant” is an exaggeration. There is no menu, no wait service. Food is made in advance, throughout the day, and presented cafeteria style. Do not look askance. The steam-table joint is based on an honorable and beloved class of establishment in Thailand known as raan khao kaeng, or rice-curry shop, sometimes just a sidewalk stall with giant pots and a few plastic chairs that patrons circle and stalk."}]
drinks: $ (inexpensive)

Title: Toné-Café
Summary: Primarily a takeout spot, Toné-Café is an offshoot of a restaurant in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, whose owners hope to make Georgian cuisine more accessible to those outside the neighborhood.
Review: [{"Review":"In Georgian, supra is the word for both a feast and the tablecloth that vanishes under it, every inch colonized by dishes that only increase in number, hour after hour. (A proper supra may last three days.)"},{"Review":"At Toné-Café, which opened in April near Gramercy Park, there are no tablecloths, nor tables to put them on. Diners commandeer a few stools at a counter barely deep enough to hold a single dish. Food comes quickly, on paper plates or encased in plastic tubs, originally destined for takeout."}]
drinks: Adjaruli khachapuri; chabostnili (eggplant salad); bazhe (chicken in walnut sauce); chakapuli (veal with tarragon and sour plums); lamb khinkali (dumplings). Prices $3.50 to $7.80.

Title: Gramercy Tavern
Summary: The enduring appeal of Gramercy Tavern transcends individual elements like atmosphere, menu and even service. It springs from a sense of safety and reassurance that is kept vital by acts of imagination.
Review: [{"Review":"Long before it turned 22 last month, Gramercy Tavern had settled into classic status. It is a classic, but there’s a downside to putting a restaurant in that category. The more familiar something is, the harder it is to see."},{"Review":"Like the other restaurants in Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group, Gramercy Tavern is virtually synonymous with a certain style of service. Cheerful, wholesome, engaging, proactive, the servers are the sort you’d be comfortable leaving young children with. (Mr. Meyer could run a great babysitting company.) Whether we walk into the easygoing front tavern or reserve a table in the more expensive and ceremonious dining room in the back, we take for granted that the service will be very good."}]
Recommended-dishes: The back dining room is dressy but not starchy; the tavern is looser, with a long and busy bar, but many still treat it like a destination. The baseline service is very good, and servers are often adept at finding chances to make a meal memorable.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Flip
Summary: New York's most comprehensive hamburger restaurant is in the basement of Bloomingdale's.
Review: [{"Review":"IN New York’s increasingly sophisticated hamburger scene, buns and condiments play their roles, but the meat is the star."},{"Review":"At least that’s been the case since the wholesaler Pat LaFrieda created Shake Shack’s custom blend of beef cuts. With that, a headliner was born. Now Mr. LaFrieda supplies chopped beef for some of the best burgers in the city, from the Spotted Pig to Five Napkin Burger. So when three places opened recently, they naturally turned to him"}]
drinks: null

Title: Market Table
Summary: What makes Market Table work are precisely those attributes supposedly prized most in anxious times. What makes it special is how expertly it embodies them.
Review: [{"Review":"WE’RE all watching, all worrying, those of us who love restaurants and believe that the world is better off with more of them."},{"Review":"How many will fail, and how quickly? Are the signs of a culinary slowdown already upon us?"}]
Recommended-dishes: Two simple rooms with exposed brick are enlivened by an open kitchen and two enormous windows onto the Greenwich Village scene.
drinks: Loud.

Title: Carla Hall’s Southern Kitchen
Summary: In a small, casual corner spot, Carla Hall, a host of “The Chew”, pays tribute to the menacingly spicy fried chicken of Prince’s and other places in Nashville.
Review: [{"Review":"For a long time, very few people thought there was money to be made selling hot chicken. This is almost certainly because for a long time, very few people outside certain neighborhoods in Nashville knew what hot chicken was."},{"Review":"The ones who did know usually lived somewhere near Prince’s Hot Chicken Shack, which was known as Prince’s BBQ Chicken Shack until it was taken over by a member of the family who thought it was time to acknowledge that what the Princes did to chicken had nothing to do with barbecue. Prince’s is and always was a fried-chicken restaurant."}]
Recommended-dishes: A bright, cheerful little corner with counter service, very few tables and several ledges with stools. Servers are very warm, but can be scattered when there’s a rush.
address:
115 Columbia Street,
                             Columbia Street Waterfront District
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Saltie
Summary: A tiny sandwich shop where breads are baked in-house and the dessert case is filled with 10 or more different pastries.
Review: [{"Review":"LATELY, foods at the thrifty end of the dining spectrum have been reworked, renewed and sometimes completely reimagined: fried chicken, pizza and hamburgers have never tasted better."},{"Review":"Add to that list the sandwich, another easy meal that can be far greater than its humble parts. At least that’s the case at Saltie 378 Metropolitan Avenue (Havemeyer Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 387-4777; saltieny.com, a tiny sandwich shop that’s little more than two counters, a few stools and a thick coat of white paint that seems inspired by the Shelter Island ferry."}]
drinks: null

Title: Salvation Burger
Summary: At Salvation Burger, the chef April Bloomfield zeroes in on what the people want and dispenses with almost everything else; three of the five main courses are burgers, and all five come on a bun.
Review: [{"Review":"April Bloomfield and Ken Friedman’s newest restaurant, inside the Pod 51 Hotel on East 51st Street, is called Salvation Burger. I can’t say that the first word of the name filled me with hope. The last time this chef and her business partner offered us salvation in a Pod hotel, they gave us Salvation Taco, a thronged taqueria designed for, and seemingly run by, people who don’t know what a taco is."},{"Review":"That second word was promising, though. Ms. Bloomfield definitely knows what a burger is."}]
Recommended-dishes: A deep, wide barroom with most seating on stools and benches. Servers are bright, cheery and T-shirted.
drinks: Moderate to moderately loud.

Title: DBGB Kitchen and Bar
Summary: Daniel Boulud tries downtown on for size with a casually elegant sausage and burger bar that offers great French pleasures alongside the ground meat.
Review: [{"Review":"HEY, ho, let’s go! Daniel Boulud, one of our more gregarious and intelligent restaurateurs, a four-star chef for his Daniel on East 65th Street, owner of three other restaurants in Manhattan, two more in Vancouver, and one each in Las Vegas, Palm Beach and Beijing, has opened a sausage joint near the corner of the Bowery and Houston Street. It’s a mosh pit’s distance from the birthplace of American punk rock."},{"Review":"He’s called it DBGB, a play on CBGB, the club at 315 Bowery that first brought the neighborhood underage kids with shaved heads  — and later its cachet."}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Kristalbelli
Summary: Korean barbecue goes upscale, with smokeless grills made of crystal, sommeliers and prices to match.
Review: [{"Review":"8 West 36th Street; (212) 290-2211; kristalbelli.com."},{"Review":"At upscale barbecue restaurants in Seoul, the hostess will not only take your coat, but also seal it in plastic: it’s protection from the grease and smoke that normally accompany the meeting of meat, marinade and fire."}]
drinks: Jeon (savory pancakes, for sharing), japchae, gujeolpan, galbi (short ribs), bulgogi jungol with "risotto," bibimbap, sweet potato dessert, rice cake dessert, sesame dessert.

Title: Nougatine at Jean Georges
Summary: Though it rarely comes up in conversations about favorite Jean-Georges Vongerichten restaurants, Nougatine has been one of the most dependable, year in and year out.
Review: [{"Review":"YES, Nougatine. You didn’t forget about it, did you?"},{"Review":"I hope not. So does Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who established it 15 years ago as the easygoing bistro next door to the demure elegance of Jean Georges, Audrey Tautou to the flagship’s Catherine Deneuve. Since then, New Yorkers have come to rely on Nougatine at Jean Georges, to give the name that nobody ever uses, for working lunches that could be expensed without waking up the auditors, yet they also tended to take it for granted. It has never been reviewed before in The New York Times, and it rarely comes up in conversations about favorite Vongerichten restaurants, although it is one of the most dependable."}]
Recommended-dishes: A sleek modern bistro with paper place mats on walnut-tone tables.
address:
One Central Park West,
                             Upper West Side
drinks: Moderate, but lively.

Title: Hecho en Dumbo
Summary: Hecho en Dumbo offers the big flavors of Mexico City, stripped down to fundamentals.
Review: [{"Review":"HUITLACOCHE, a corn fungus that’s a delicacy in Mexican cuisine, doesn’t always fulfill its funky potential. Too often it’s bland and mushy, a bit of name-dropping on the menu that doesn’t do much on the plate."},{"Review":"Not so at Hecho en Dumbo, which recently moved to the Bowery after three years in Brooklyn. Here the quesadillas de huitlacoche ($10) have a flavor falling somewhere between black trumpet mushrooms and a damp basement. Two fresh tortillas are stuffed with the firm, ash-colored corn and cheese and then folded, crimped and fried until crisp. The success is in the shopping. Unlike most huitlacoche in the United States, it isn’t canned; it’s flash-frozen, from D’Artagnan."}]
drinks: Guacamole, tostadas de ceviche, ensalada tricolor, quesadillas de huitlacoche, tacos de costilla, queso fundido de chorizo, pozole rojo.

Title: Tut’s Hub Royal Cuisine
Summary: A few blocks south of the Little Egypt strip in Astoria, Queens, Tut’s Hub stands three stories, crowned by the sun disk of Aten and guarded by a statue of the warrior goddess Sekhmet. The surroundings are lofty, but few dishes rise above $10, orders are placed at the cash register and the best dishes have roots in the streets.
Review: [{"Review":"At night, the sun blazes over Tut’s Hub Royal Cuisine, a three-story restaurant on Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, a few blocks south of the strip known as Little Egypt."},{"Review":"Once this was a Wendy’s. Now the solar disc of the god Aten crowns the building, its rays reaching down with human hands. Heads of Hathor, a cow-eared goddess, watch over the sidewalk from atop stocky columns. In lieu of a hostess looms a shining statue of the warrior goddess Sekhmet, whose many names include Giver of Ecstasies, Lady of the Silent Roar Within and One Before Whom Evil Trembles."}]
drinks: Mixed grill with lamb chops, kebabs and koftas; hawawshi; kushari; savory feteer with mixed meat; sweet feteer with powdered sugar and custard. Prices $4.95 to $14.95.

Title: Cowgirl SeaHorse
Summary: An offshoot of the Cowgirl Hall of Fame, Cowgirl SeaHorse is open and fun — and a house margarita paired with warm, salty tortilla chips does much to recall the freak flagship's mood of tolerance.
Review: [{"Review":"COWGIRL SEAHORSE"},{"Review":"259 Front Street (Dover Street), Financial District; (212) 608-7873."}]
drinks: null

Title: Ducks Eatery
Summary: Exciting things are happening at Ducks Eatery, where a bayou smokehouse meets a backpacker pipe dream.
Review: [{"Review":"“BE sure to suck out the shrimp heads,” the waitress instructed. Always sound advice, particularly so at Ducks Eatery, where a hypodermic needle is poked under the carapace with a solution of vinegar, star anise and house-made ssamjang (a Korean mixture of fermented soybean and chile pastes that is longer on funk than heat)."},{"Review":"There’s more: the liquid is thickened with agar-agar and sealed in with a quick dip of the heads in liquid nitrogen. Only then are the shrimp tossed on the grill and, finally, painted with whipped lardo."}]
drinks: Charred head-on shrimp; St. Louis ribs; crispy pig ears; yakamein; nasi ulam rice; pipi kaula; chicken wings; beignets.

Title: Socarrat
Summary: Churros are the supermodels of the doughnut world: long, skinny and vaguely extraterrestrial. At La Churreria, they are moist inside yet dry to the touch, crisp and fluffy and chewy all at once; dunk them in the accompanying hot chocolate, which is served in a coffee cup and so dark and thick it almost counts as a pudding.
Review: [{"Review":"284 Mulberry Street (Houston Street); (212) 219-0400; lachurrerianyc.com."},{"Review":"Churros are the supermodels of the doughnut world: long, skinny and vaguely extraterrestrial. At La Churreria in NoLIta, they come to your table straight from a bath of hot oil ($6 for a half-dozen with chocolate)."}]
drinks: Churros with chocolate; churros rellenos with chocolate, crema, or dulce de leche; “Madrileño” bocata with crispy calamari; “Ibiza” bocata with grilled chicken and chimichurri.

Title: The Commodore
Summary: A dive bar with great vaguely Southern food that feels as if it’s been around forever.
Review: [{"Review":"LIKE all good dive bars, the Commodore keeps it simple."},{"Review":"There are paper place-mat menus the color of Aqua Velva, C-list video games (Championship Sprint, Crazy Climber) and no waiters. Drinks are served until 4 every morning, and garnishes are speared with plastic sword-shaped toothpicks. Most of the cocktails listed on the menu board  next to the cash register are $7 or $8."}]
drinks: Chicken with biscuits, hot fish sandwich, hamburger, French fries, green chili hominy, snap pea and egg, cold green beans with potatoes and pickled onion, green salad, Saltie potato salad.

Title: M & T Restaurant
Summary: The cuisine of Qingdao is prepared with elegant simplicity at this small Flushing restaurant.
Review: [{"Review":"M & T Restaurant"},{"Review":" 44-09 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens; (718) 539-4100. "}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Prime & Beyond
Summary: A sleek, modern spot offering bargains in prime-grade steak, served with simple Korean-style sides.
Review: [{"Review":"90 East 10th Street, (Third Avenue), East Village, (212) 505-0033, primeandbeyond.com"},{"Review":"Is New York ready for a serious steakhouse without hash browns or shrimp cocktail? Kyu and Kevin Lee, Korean-American brothers who opened Prime & Beyond in the East Village this summer, believe so.  Like the original Prime & Beyond in Fort Lee, N.J., the Manhattan restaurant serves wonderful beef, all of it prime, at below-market prices —  alongside a few excellent Korean and Japanese side dishes."}]
drinks: Steaks; burger and rice with fried egg; spicy pork bowl; oxtail soup; grilled short rib; scallion salad; kimchi; French fries; king oyster mushrooms.

Title: Kulushkät
Summary: The falafel at this modest and mostly takeout shop in Park Slope is crisp yet moist, airy yet creamy.
Review: [{"Review":"446C Dean Street (Fifth Avenue), Park Slope, Brooklyn, (347) 799-1972, kulushkat.com."},{"Review":"To properly judge a falafel joint, you must first taste the falafel solo, without the interventions of hummus, tahini or that punch-to-the-gut hot sauce, zhug."}]
drinks: Gilly falafel, Mediterranean chicken falafel, eggplant à la Yafa.

Title: Mimi
Summary: It’s an updated version of the small French restaurant everybody dreams of finding in the Village. The kitchen is small and still figuring things out, but it has a clear vision of French food as a celebration of appetite, an occasion to eat with joy and lust.
Review: [{"Review":"It took three dinners at Mimi before I saw the restaurant that had other people so excited."},{"Review":"Mimi barely ruffled the waters of the crowded pond of New York dining when it materialized on a quiet Greenwich Village block last fall. The partners had never owned a restaurant before. The chef, Liz Johnson, was 25 years old. Although she had been cooking for a decade, it was hard to draw a bead on her busy work history."}]
Recommended-dishes: Simple, intimate, neighborly. Servers are charming, solicitous.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Eleven Madison Park
Summary: Both the kitchen and the dining room staff try as hard as any to bring delight to the table with every course at Eleven Madison Park, and they succeed so often that only the most determinedly grumpy souls could resist.
Review: [{"Review":"Can a restaurant still succeed when it fails at what it says it wants to do?"},{"Review":"This is not a question critics ask every day. But then the place in question, Eleven Madison Park, is not a restaurant where most of us would or could eat every day."}]
Recommended-dishes: The high-ceilinged, generously windowed Art Deco space manages to feel both grand and intimate.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Hearth
Summary: When he opened Hearth in 2003, Marco Canora, its chef, set out to adapt the transparency of Tuscan cooking to his own region and time of year. Mr. Canora gets few points for the originality of his vision, but for his fidelity to it, his score is off the charts.
drinks: null

Title: Le Relais de Venise L’Entrecôte
Summary: Cheerful bistro setting offers paintings of Venetian scenes; good flowers; candlelight.
drinks: null

Title: Wilfie & Nell
Summary: The food at Wilfie & Nell, named for the grandparents of brothers Mark and Simon Gibson, is resolutely pub fare.
Review: [{"Review":"Wilfie & Nell"},{"Review":"228 West Fourth Street (West 10th Street); (212) 242-2990; wilfieandnell.com."}]
drinks: null

Title: Daniel
Summary: Daniel serves exquisitely sensitive, profoundly seasonal, fundamentally French cooking.
Review: [{"Review":"Your job may be worrying you, or your father’s health, or your own. You may have been up at 2 that morning drafting a better ending for a long-ago memory. But certain restaurants, if you can afford them, can knock down the barriers between you and happiness for a few hours. Every taste seems to transport you to another world, while every gesture of the staff convinces you that you live in the privileged center of this one."},{"Review":"Daniel, which turned 20 this year, can make you feel that way. Does chilled pea soup sound like the stuff of privilege? It is when it comes from this kitchen, where Jean François Bruel has been the executive chef since 2003, and which Daniel Boulud, the proprietor, watches over from a windowed perch above the saucepans and sieves."}]
Recommended-dishes: An old-world neoclassical colonnade frames a quietly modern dining room.
drinks: More than a murmur but considerably less than a din.

Title: Xixa
Summary: At Xixa, which opened in December in South Williamsburg, Mexico is merely a starting point for a kind of culinary free association that can be borderline loco or brilliant, sometimes both at once.
Review: [{"Review":"The jagged line of powder down the plate is worm salt, tawny and fine. No explanation is given beyond its name, which is literal: it is a commingling of salt and ground-up maguey worms, or, more precisely, the larvae of moths who feed on the agave plants from which mezcal is made."},{"Review":"This turns out to be a surprisingly elegant, and traditional, way to eat the worm, without squishiness or an audience of baying frat boys. First a sip of mezcal, in this case barrel-aged Sombra, a mouthful of smoke, cream and scorched violets; then a lick of worm salt, tasting of mushrooms; and, last, a crush of blood orange between the teeth. But for the squeamish, there is also a slash of black sesame salt, a nontraditional flourish from the chef."}]
drinks: Chicken sopes; chilaquiles; Thai esquites; shrimp gorditas; tostadas; carrots elote; butterfish tartare; “guacamole nam prik num”; frico-dilla; carnitas; tequila bandera.

Title: Fort Defiance
Summary: In a part of Red Hook that feels like a sleepy Maine port, Fort Defiance is part bar, part restaurant and part serious coffee joint.
Review: [{"Review":"NEW YORK used to be  a second-string city when it came to coffee. No longer."},{"Review":"Over the last two years, more than 40 new cafes and coffee bars have joined a small, dedicated group of establishments where coffee making is treated like an art, or at least a high form of craft."}]
drinks: null

Title: Sariling Atin
Summary: Past the shelves of egg cracklets and adobo-flavored corn nuts at Sariling Atin is a modest dining room, where food is ordered turo-turo (point-point) style, as in a cafeteria, and spooned into plastic-foam bowls.
Review: [{"Review":"Fish are stacked on the glass over the steam table, fried whole without interfering batter, all crackly veneer and quick-tearing flesh. There are galunggong, like swollen cigars with the flavor of a shyer mackerel; pompano in puckering silver; and, best of all, bangus (pronounced ban-GOOSE), or milkfish, flaky and sweet, stripped of bones and butterflied flat, but with the brittle fletch of a tail intact."},{"Review":"Below are 15 chafing pans, brimming with stews and noodles. Extra pans have been balanced on top, along with china plates of banana-ketchup-glazed beef and chicken skewers, which a glance around the room reveals that everyone has plundered."},{"Review":"Sariling Atin, whose name in Tagalog means “our own,” opened in April in Elmhurst, Queens, on a block once dominated by furniture showrooms. From the outside, it looks like a small grocery, with a “Send Money” sign and the current Philippine peso exchange rate posted in the window."},{"Review":"Red Christmas globes of Edam cheese, for the Filipino celebration of Noche Buena, linger up front by the cash register. But past the shelves of egg cracklets and adobo-flavored corn nuts, Datu Puti cane vinegar and Andok’s Litson sauce, is a modest dining room."},{"Review":"Food is ordered turo-turo (point-point) style, as in a cafeteria, and spooned into plastic-foam bowls. Rice or pancit (noodles) with one side is $4.50; add two more sides and you’re at $9.50 and already full. Still, you will want both rice and pancit, particularly pancit palabok, egg noodles blanched and tumbled in a briny gravy, with a crush of chicharrónes."},{"Review":"Among the rotating dishes may be kalderetang kambing, goat cooked until it shivers apart, in a meld of tomatoes, olives, pickles and — an essential of the Filipino kitchen — liver spread, which gives it a strangely mushroomy undertow. Seafood kare-kare is equally rich, with a base of shrimp stock thickened with peanut butter and tomato sauce and loaded with banana blossoms, long beans and eggplant. It is served with a dab of bagoong, tiny fermented shrimp, and is nothing without it."},{"Review":"Much of the buffet is committed to pork: dominoes of crispy pork belly, with gilded bubbles and a snaking smoke; Bicol Express, a near curry from southern Luzon, with pork steeped in coconut milk, fermented shrimp paste, ginger and serious chiles; mongo, an extraordinary stew in which pork is subordinate to humble mung beans, with tendrils of spinach and contours of chile, lime and patis (fish sauce). Sisig is the one disappointment, made with pork belly but no pig face, as is custom, and presented like a cold salad, tossed with lemon juice, onion and more of that liver spread, so that the deep-fried nubs of pork lose their crunch."},{"Review":"The owners, Celso Concepcion, known as Nilo, and his wife, Rosario, known as Rose — in the Philippines, nicknames are used more often than official ones — run another grocery-restaurant in Toms River, N.J. Two decades ago, Rose immigrated to the United States to work as a nurse’s aide, sending money home to Nilo and their daughter Rocel for years until they were able to join her. Now 25, Rocel manages the family’s Queens outpost, although she hopes to go to dentistry school one day. (Nilo’s cousin Edgardo Gonzales oversees the kitchen.)"},{"Review":"The dining room, decorated by Rose, is efficient and cheerful. A sunflower made from painted banana leaves brightens one wall, a mosaic of mirror and capiz shells another. (“My mother loves Pier 1 Imports,” Rocel says with a laugh.) Filipino soap operas flutter and heave on the TV overhead."},{"Review":"On a recent evening, an off-duty doorman hovered by the counter, his jacket with epaulets unbuttoned and swinging. Every table was full, with knots of women wielding substantial handbags, fathers and pigtailed daughters and boys in United States Navy caps and Ecko hoodies who were supplementing dinner with a bag of pork cracklings and Mountain Dew."},{"Review":"It is not quite translatable, what it means in Tagalog to call something “our own.” When the Concepcions opened their first shop eight years ago, they identified it, obliquely, as an “oriental grocery.” Here the word on the awning is “Filipino.”"}]
drinks: Mongo (mung bean stew); kalderetang kambing (goat stew); Bicol Express; fried bangus (milkfish); pancit palabok.

Title: Totto Ramen
Summary: A simple noodle shop.
Review: [{"Review":"JAPAN is dotted with wonderfully workaday ramen shops, places that are especially compelling when the weather turns cold. The lunch crowd squeezes into a narrow space shrouded in steam pouring from soup bowls, stock brews on open flames beyond the counter, and beside it a man pulls fresh noodles. The only sounds come from the bubbling pots and the clatter of chopsticks and spoons in bowls. Outside, the air is cold and thin; inside, the soup is hot and rich. Lunch at these places is, at once, otherworldly and comforting."},{"Review":"New York has been hit lately with a run of ramen shops of its own. Two of the newest are the East and West Side cousins, respectively, Hide-Chan Ramen and Totto Ramen, on polar ends of 52nd Street. Both are owned by Bobby Munekata, of Yakitori Totto, who worked on the menus with a chef from Hakata, Japan — pork-based ramen’s home region. Neither spot has nearly the brilliance of Ippudo NY, in the East Village, or the breadth of other Midtown ramen shops like Menchanko-Tei, but each has its specialties, and one or two of them are very worth eating."}]
drinks: null

Title: Toloache
Summary: Despite its strange purple facade, this Mexican bistro is worth a second look.
Review: [{"Review":"IT is difficult to eat well in the theater district, even if you’re in on the game and have Esca on speed dial."},{"Review":"Joe Allen is a treat after a show, for lounging amid the posters advertising first-night flops. Sardi’s is best during one, empty and sweet, with Rialto lawyers arguing Guettel versus Sondheim over cannelloni au gratin."}]
Recommended-dishes: If bistros were Mexican, and vin rouge were made with tequila and lime juice, Toloache could be in Paris.
drinks: Crashingly loud during the pretheater rush.

Title: A-Wah
Summary: This bright, homey restaurant serves more than a dozen varieties of the Hong Kong specialty called bo zai fan, or "clay pot rice" in Cantonese.
Review: [{"Review":"5 Catherine Street (East Broadway), (212) 925-8308."},{"Review":"As you step inside this shoebox of a restaurant just south of Chatham Square, you will spot a half-dozen or so sealed pots on the cooktop behind the counter."}]
drinks: $$ (moderate)

Title: Machiavelli
Summary: A grand, artsy homage to Italian food, with Renaissance-style murals, live piano music and a dedicated pasta chef.
Review: [{"Review":"519 Columbus Avenue (85th Street); (212) 724-2658; machiavellinyc.com"},{"Review":"Eating at the grandiose Machiavelli is like visiting a museum of Italian food — complete with long-winded exhibition catalogs. Reams of paper arrive with the menu, bearing tales of the muralist who decorated the walls, the ceramist who designed the plates, the coloratura soprano who even now is singing into your ear. (There is live music at dinner and sometimes at lunch.)"}]
drinks: Frittatas; crescentine with salumi; salads; pastas and pizzas; veal piccata; grilled trout with tomatoes and capers; mashed potatoes with Parmesan; ice creams and sorbets.

Title: Allswell
Summary: The best of Nate Smith's cooking shows real sensitivity to ingredients, with a few British touches he picked up during his time at the Spotted Pig.
Review: [{"Review":"124 Bedford Avenue (North 10th Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (347) 799-2743, allswellnyc.tumblr.com/."},{"Review":"I am one of about 20 people who caught Nate Smith’s monthlong run at Dean Street in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, and I’m glad I did. Mr. Smith, the former chef de cuisine of the Spotted Pig, was doing some very strong, well-considered gastropub cooking before he complained about the television and the jukebox at this longtime neighborhood tavern, and was fired."}]
drinks: null

Title: Talde
Summary: A veteran of Vong in Chicago and Buddakan in New York before his time on “Top Chef,” Dale Talde has a well-polished knack for translating Asian dishes for popular tastes.
Review: [{"Review":"CHARGING into a restaurant during its first weeks of life used to be an amateur move, guaranteeing long waits, clueless service and food that could generously be described as a work in progress. Diners with any wisdom and self-control waited a few months, or even years, while the place hit its stride."},{"Review":"But now, restaurants have to stun from the start. They open amid a frenzy of media attention from bloggers, Yelpers, tweeters, reporters and critics. Then, before long, the reviews are all in, opinions are set and the swarm moves on. It takes, at most, a couple of months, and smart restaurateurs and chefs work at the top of their abilities until it’s over."}]
Recommended-dishes: A simple local Asian spot with extraordinary mahogany woodwork.
drinks: Tolerable.

Title: Schaller’s Stube
Summary: The sausages at this annex to Schaller & Weber make a mockery of the buns meant to contain them.
Review: [{"Review":"At Schaller’s Stube, the kielbasa is almost obscene in scale, python-thick and making a mockery of the hot-dog bun suffocated somewhere beneath it. A band of melted American cheese has tattooed itself along the top. Furls of bacon, strewn over half its length, appear in blossom; chicharrones nestle around it like clouds. Below, invisible to the eye, are spoonfuls of bacon pulverized into jam, with a slow-flowering sweetness like that of dark, difficult chocolate."},{"Review":"This is no more a hot dog than Schaller’s Stube is a hot-dog stand. Jeremy Schaller and Jesse Denes, the owners, call it a sausage bar. They introduced it in July as an annex to Schaller & Weber, the venerable butcher shop that Mr. Schaller’s grandfather opened in 1937 on Second Avenue at 86th Street, in a part of Yorkville that was then known as Kleindeutschland, or Little Germany."}]
drinks: The Classic (bratwurst with mustard and sauerkraut); Schaller Double (bacon-Cheddar bratwurst with American cheese and crispy bacon); King Ludwig (leberkäse with radishes and sweet mustard); Saigon Special (bauernwurst with daikon-carrot slaw and sriracha aioli); weisswurst with sweet mustard. Prices $2 to $14.

Title: Baoburg
Summary: Baoburg’s idiosyncratic menu owes as much to classical European technique as it does to the cross-cultural upbringing of the chef, Suchanan Aksornnan.
Review: [{"Review":"Here come the devils on horseback, that relic of dinner parties past: prunes and dates cowled in bacon and thrust onto skewers, chewy, crunchy, sweet and salty at once. Except that these devils are in Japanese garb, adorned with nitsume, the dark, sticky sauce that traditionally accompanies eel; squiggles of extra-tangy Kewpie mayonnaise; and translucent bonito flakes like blanched confetti."},{"Review":"This isn’t globe-trotting for its own sake. Mayo adds creaminess, while bonito and nitsume intensify the sweet-salty hostilities. The dish has whimsy and logic, and is a fine introduction to the personal geography of Suchanan Aksornnan, the chef at Baoburg, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn."}]
address:
126 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn,
                             Williamsburg
drinks: Bacon-wrapped prunes and dates takoyaki; grilled lamb rice ball skewer; gambas al ajillo; brussels sprouts; duck confit linguine; braised lamb shoulder stew.

Title: Engeline’s Restaurant and Bakeshop
Summary: The pork dishes stand out at Engeline's in Woodside, one of New York’s few outposts of Filipino cooking.
Review: [{"Review":"“I’M experiencing pork vertigo,” a dining companion said."},{"Review":"We’d barely started our meal at Engeline’s Restaurant and  Bakeshop, one of New York’s few outposts of Filipino cooking, under the No. 7 train in Woodside, Queens. But already our table was crowded with three platters of pork."}]
drinks: null

Title: Shuko
Summary: Jimmy Lau and Nick Kim, the chefs and owners, rose to the top of Masa Takayama’s restaurant group. What’s impressive about their own restaurant, Shuko, is how many times the chefs ring the bells without resorting to clichéd indulgences.
Review: [{"Review":"“You like spicy?” Jimmy Lau asked from behind the counter at Shuko, the new restaurant just below Union Square where he and his partner, Nick Kim, prepare an elevated and memorable species of Japanese food. Before I could answer, he handed me a spicy tuna roll that would casually knock over my ideas about spicy tuna rolls, and spice, and tuna."},{"Review":"Pickled red Thai chiles sat on top of the roll, chopped to bits and ready for action. The tuna underneath was soft sinew cut from the belly of a bluefin. It was grilled until the fat ran, until it soaked through the rice in its crisp nori wrapper and dripped out the bottom of the roll and into my palm."}]
Recommended-dishes: A fun, secluded, relaxed sushi bar, with the emphasis on bar; the mood is equal parts cocktail hide-out and Japanese restaurant.
drinks: Music plays but conversation prevails.

Title: Locol
Summary: The chefs Daniel Patterson and Roy Choi are trying to do so many things with their insurgent fast-food chain, Locol, that it almost has to fall short somewhere. What is surprising, though, is that they would have so much trouble with the food.
Review: [{"Review":"OAKLAND, Calif. — The chefs Daniel Patterson and Roy Choi are trying to do so many things with their insurgent fast-food chain, Locol, that it almost has to fall short somewhere. What I didn’t expect before I ate at the branch here was that the big problem would turn out to be the food."},{"Review":"Mr. Choi, who made his name selling Korean tacos from trucks that prowled Los Angeles, and Mr. Patterson, who has gently pushed California cuisine forward at his restaurant Coi in San Francisco, set themselves an ambitious project. To start, they intend to build a network of small restaurants that people in some of the country’s poorest, most neglected urban neighborhoods can afford. Beyond that, though, the chefs hope that their example of progressive labor practices, interior design attuned to the pulse of the city and cooking that shows responsibility for the health of both customers and the environment will spark a reformation of the fast-food industry."}]
Recommended-dishes: A monochromatic and playful fast-food restaurant with counter service and big, movable wooden cubes that serve as tables and chairs. Servers are helpful, proactive and extroverted, whether at the counter, the touch-screen ordering kiosks or the compost-and-recycling drop holes.
drinks: Classic hip-hop at moderate volumes.

Title: The Clocktower
Summary: The Clocktower plays a familiar game, the private club that has accidentally let you in, but the cooking of Jason Atherton, an English chef who worked under Gordon Ramsay, has the peculiar idea of cooking to make other people happy, not to reflect his own glory.
Review: [{"Review":"If you hope dinner at the Clocktower will get you a backstage view of the ticking cogs at the top of the former Metropolitan Life Tower, forget it. The restaurant is on the second floor of the New York Edition hotel, which opened in the skyscraper at the foot of Madison Avenue in May. Marriott and Ian Schrager, who run the place, brought in the restaurateur Stephen Starr to operate the Clocktower."},{"Review":"To get there, you can take the elevator from the lobby, or you can disappear up what looks like a big white cocoon into a tight spiral staircase. Upstairs, burning candles in glass lanterns flank the floor of the elevator bank. Somebody, maybe you, will notice this too late and kick one over."}]
Recommended-dishes: A grand office built for insurance executives, redone in the mode of a private London club. Service is very good, though the servers are asked to perform a distracting amount of tableside stage business.
drinks: Moderately loud.

Title: Almond
Summary: A 170-seat branch of the popular French bistro in Bridgehampton, N.Y.
drinks: null

Title: Estiatorio Milos
Summary: Since 1997, Milos has served Greek cuisine, particularly whole fish and shellfish kept on ice near the open kitchen, to loyal customers who can afford the forbidding prices.
Review: [{"Review":"After a long and grueling winter, nothing lifts the spirits in springtime quite like an old-fashioned fish fight."},{"Review":"Limani opened in November around the corner from the Rockefeller Center skating rink. Its menu is Greek, and its strength is formidably expensive seafood, which up until the moment it is laid on the grill can be found spread out on a small mountain of ice at the edge of the open kitchen. The modern dining room subliminally evokes the Aegean and has space for nearly 200 people at tables draped with white cloths."}]
Recommended-dishes: A striking room with white marble floors, an infinity pool and a gleaming mobile of small fish.
drinks: Placid.

Title: Taiwan Bear House
Summary: At Taiwan Bear House in Chinatown, biodegradable wooden boxes are packed with rice and topped with crusty pork chop, slabs of pork belly or chicken twice fried in the night-market style.
Review: [{"Review":"Pell Street these days is two quiet blocks, no more, but Chinatown was born here, where Doyers Street dead-ends into Pell, where tour guides still talk of tongs and mah-jongg."},{"Review":"At night, on Pell’s eastern end, pilgrims queue for soup dumplings at Joe’s Shanghai. They may not notice Taiwan Bear House, which opened last June, with its teddy-bear logo suggesting just another perky bubble-tea shop."}]
drinks: Golden crust pork chop bento; original minced pork bento; night market crispy chicken bento; fried chicken leg bento.

Title: Han Joo
Summary: Han Joo offers barbecue by way of the spa, each tabletop grill an infrared sauna in miniature, the pulse of heat from the crystal cooking everything to eerie evenness.
Review: [{"Review":"ON A CRYSTAL SLAB lie scarlet ribbons of meat with a bridal trim of fat, hissing and collapsing. Gone is the thunderhead of smoke you expect at a Korean barbecue joint, the constant scraping of the hot plate, the burned debris. At Han Joo, each tabletop grill uses infrared heat to cook everything to an eerie evenness."},{"Review":"You miss the drama, but it’s hard to argue with results. The meat — short rib sheared off the bone in featherweight strips; duck as fragile as tissue paper and curling into ringlets; pork belly that has wallowed a lifetime in garlic — is tender, retrieved from the grill moments before dissolution. The juices trickle down the canted slab into heaps of kimchi that the waitress snips apart with scissors."}]
drinks: Galbi tang; soon dubu chigae; doenjang chigae; sulun tang; mool naeng myun; garlic pork belly; galbi; duck dae pae.

Title: Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill
Summary: At Pravue Cafe in Ridgewood, Queens, the menu alternates between dishes that look to the West and those that stay true to Albania, made from recipes passed down through generations.
Review: [{"Review":"The fries at Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill taste as if they have taken a tumble in a perfect bowl of ramen and have somehow still emerged crisp. First fried, then baked, they arrive slightly sticky with a truffle glaze and pecorino Romano gone lax in the oven. But the verve comes from Vegeta, a synthesis of salt, sugar, spice and dehydrated vegetables engineered a half-century ago in Yugoslavia."},{"Review":"Sead Duraku, known as Sal, opened Pravue in June near the southeastern border of Ridgewood, Queens, a neighborhood with one of the largest Albanian populations in the city. Outside hovers a two-headed black eagle, wings outstretched on a red shingle. It is a descendant of the coat of arms borne into battle by Albanian noblemen in the Middle Ages, fighting for freedom from the Ottoman Empire."}]
drinks: Bureks with house-made yogurt; cevapi with kaymak; stuffed cabbage; grosh; Vegeta fries. Prices $5 to $20.

Title: Acme
Summary: One of the founding chefs of Noma in Copenhagen treats familiar ingredients with an uncommon gentleness and respect.
Review: [{"Review":"SOME chefs storm into the city like an invading navy, gunships of publicity thundering on the horizon."},{"Review":"Mads Refslund slipped into town in January as quietly as a canoe."}]
Recommended-dishes: A loose take on a large and well-worn bistro, with cafe chairs and an arching mirror along one wall. The long bar up front caters to solo diners; a downstairs lounge with a bar menu is open late. There can be a bit of old-school downtown chill at the door, but at the table servers are quite solicitous, even if you suspect they don’t quite understand what’s happening in the kitchen.
drinks: Intense at its peak.

Title: ABC Cocina
Summary: The menu, a collaboration of Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Dan Kluger, rummages through the cupboards of Spanish-speaking countries.
Review: [{"Review":"Apparently there are people who believe that the Internet has made restaurant critics irrelevant. I’d like to direct their attention to this text from the ABC Cocina Web site: “abc cocina & michelin star chef jean-georges vongerichten welcome you to our modern global exchange celebrating local craft and international culture, a fusion of tradition and innovation uniting yesterday and tomorrow.”"},{"Review":"Got that? There’s more: “experience the vision of abc home curation, a romantic and mystical atmosphere and succumb to a dynamic love affair with an eclectic and enchanting cuisine.”"}]
Recommended-dishes: Casual; all the fixtures are for sale, which gives the room an ad hoc feeling. Walk-ins are seated at communal tables.
drinks: Not quiet.

Title: Kyo Ya
Summary: A Japanese hideaway in the middle of the East Village, known for its kaiseki dining.
Review: [{"Review":"SOME facts are beyond the reach of search engines. This is probably lucky for all of us, and it is especially lucky for those who go to eat at Kyo Ya. A Japanese hideaway in the middle of the East Village, Kyo Ya gives up its secrets slowly. Learning them is part of the adventure."},{"Review":"The restaurant, which turned five years old last month, has no Web site. Reservations cannot be made through OpenTable. Any menu you manage to turn up online is likely to be seriously out of date. If Kyo Ya has opinions about bankers or fracking, they remain untweeted."}]
Recommended-dishes: An underground sanctuary built of wood, with tables in the front, two counters and a tatami room. Service is graceful and intuitive.
drinks: Placid, but not hushed.

Title: Guy's American Kitchen & Bar
Summary: The kind of cooking Guy Fieri celebrates on television is treated with staggering disregard at his restaurant in Times Square. Even the nachos are unlovable.
Review: [{"Review":"GUY FIERI, have you eaten at your new restaurant in Times Square? Have you pulled up one of the 500 seats at Guy’s American Kitchen & Bar and ordered a meal? Did you eat the food? Did it live up to your expectations?"},{"Review":"Did panic grip your soul as you stared into the whirling hypno wheel of the menu, where adjectives and nouns spin in a crazy vortex? When you saw the burger described as “Guy’s Pat LaFrieda custom blend, all-natural Creekstone Farm Black Angus beef patty, LTOP (lettuce, tomato, onion + pickle), SMC (super-melty-cheese) and a slathering of Donkey Sauce on garlic-buttered brioche,” did your mind touch the void for a minute?"}]
Recommended-dishes: 500 seats, three levels, three bars, one chaotic mess.
address:
220 West 44th Street,
                             Times Square Theatre District
drinks: Rawk and roll, but at moderate volumes.

Title: Bati
Summary: Bati serves traditional Ethiopian food in an environment that has a slightly improvised air.
Review: [{"Review":"IN FORT GREENE, Brooklyn,  the four corners of Africa can be reached within a few blocks. With the stalwart Madiba representing the south for years, three other restaurants have staked claims  to west, east, and north."},{"Review":"ABISTRO"}]
drinks: null

Title: Raclette
Summary: At this tiny storefront, the melting surface of great half-wheels of raclette cheese is scraped down tableside over a plate of cornichons, pickled pearl onions, roasted potatoes and thin, purplish-red slices of air-dried beef. It is deeply satisfying to watch the cascade of cheese and to dig out the vegetables and meat below, as if eating fondue in reverse.
Review: [{"Review":"The chef at Raclette stood by the table, holding a great half wheel of warmed cheese that had started to blister and bubble along its exposed diameter. He tilted it, pressed a long knife to the top and scraped down. The cheese seemed to shrug, the melted surface giving way like the side of a mountain coming undone."},{"Review":"It settled on the plate in ripples that quickly congealed, half-burying the food below: little spars of cornichons, lustrous pickled pearl onions, roasted potatoes with the skins still on and viande séchée, air-dried beef in thin, purplish-red slices, delicate to the touch and seamed with salt. On the outer rim, just escaping the onslaught, were a tuft of arugula and a hunk of slightly stiff baguette, which nevertheless fulfilled its purpose as a mechanism for scooping that lush, wonderfully rank cheese."}]
drinks: Raclette Suisse; raclette Savoyarde; fig tartine; sardine tartine; croque Lolotte; croque Saint-Michel.

Title: Jams
Summary: The original Jams was one of the most influential restaurants of the 1980s, but this Jams reboot, inside the 1 Hotel Central Park, is stiff in the joints and short on joie de vivre.
Review: [{"Review":"By the early 1980s, New Yorkers knew that something major was happening in the kitchens of California. They had heard about the revolution, but most of them hadn’t tasted it until Jonathan Waxman opened Jams in 1984. Here was a report from the West Coast front lines brought by a chef fresh from Michael’s in Santa Monica and, before that, Chez Panisse in Berkeley."},{"Review":"To put it in terms readers born after 1980 will understand, this was a bit like being the first person in town to have cooked at both Noma and Relae, but bigger. Styles in food didn’t get around as fast in those days."}]
Recommended-dishes: A comfortable and casual space stripped down to bare bricks, with large windows on the street. Servers are well meaning but confused at times.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Piora
Summary: Chris Cipollone’s cooking dips into Korean cuisine, but before you file it under Asian fusion, be aware that the one thing you must do at Piora is eat some pasta.
Review: [{"Review":"You can put up with mediocre food in a restaurant that has other things going for it. When an exciting chef works in a terrible dining room, though, you feel the way you do when a friend hooks up with somebody you can’t stand. You may visit the two of them once or twice to savor the full extent of the new partner’s awfulness, but then you run for cover while you await the end."},{"Review":"That’s the reaction most diners had to Tenpenny when Chris Cipollone was the chef. Nearly everyone agreed that his food was terrific but that eating it in the charmless lobby of a Midtown hotel was like being buried alive with your last meal."}]
Recommended-dishes: An elegant if snug room with rear windows looking out on a tiny garden.
drinks: Moderate.

Title: Joe & Misses Doe
Summary: Eclectic influences, from Asian to Jewish, are combined at this small New American restaurant.
Review: [{"Review":"JOEDOE"},{"Review":"45 East First Street (First Avenue), (212) 780-0262, chefjoedoe.com"}]
drinks: null

Title: Ay Kitchen
Summary: The Turkish tastes at this Murray Hill restaurant range from bold (pan-fried calf’s liver, kofte, tarama) to a bit too mild (unspicy “spicy" chicken adana kebabs, bland octopus or white bean salads).
Review: [{"Review":"115 Lexington Avenue (28th Street), Murray Hill, (212) 213-0200, aykitchen.com."},{"Review":"Ramazan Ay, the chef and owner of Kebab House in Little Neck, N.Y., as well as this new spot in Murray Hill, doesn’t have the flair of Orhan Yegen, his former boss at Turkish Kitchen (and near-partner in an aborted Brooklyn project). But he also isn’t as rough around the edges."}]
drinks: Tarama; leeks; arnavut ciger (pan-fried calf’s liver); karniyarik (stuffed eggplant); shish kebab; karides guvec (shrimp casserole).

Title: Mission Cantina
Summary: Mission Cantina, Danny Bowien's nonconformist Mexican restaurant, charges under $10 for almost everything on the menu. For those prices, you don’t grumble too loudly when a dish fizzles.
Review: [{"Review":"IF YOU HAVE a wide-ranging appetite and more time than money, there’s never been a better time to eat in New York. Every corner of the city is churning out affordable hits of deliciousness, and a long wait is often the only obstacle between wanting some and getting some. Even acclaimed chefs are in this game now, making creative cooking more accessible than ever. And if the meal turns out to be less exciting than you had hoped, you’ve lost only a few hours and a few dollars. The next day will bring some new taste, a Filipino tapas bar or an artisanal spaetzle truck."},{"Review":"So while much of the nonconformist Mexican food at Mission Cantina is curiously unsatisfying, the disappointment does not sting the way it would if the prices were higher."}]
Recommended-dishes: Casual and fun for an hour, but not a place for lingering all night.
drinks: Fluctuates with the music volume from manageable to intimidating.

Title: Wallflower
Summary: Wallflower waits in the shadows just off Greenwich Avenue, without a sign, barely exhaling light.
Review: [{"Review":"Wallflower lies in the shadows just off Greenwich Avenue, without a sign, barely exhaling light. Inside, the space is tight in that way called bijou, two brief rooms under a tin ceiling painted gold, requiring you to lean close to your companions and reminding you that New York really does live up to its myth, as a city of half-secret places like this one."},{"Review":"Wallflower opened in the West Village in October. The front room, lined with marble counters, is devoted to elegant, occasionally roguish cocktails; the slender dining room is furnished with mirrors, orange and gray banquettes and elegant, occasionally roguish bistro fare. Each is accorded equal importance: drinks are overseen by Xavier Herit, who spent seven years as head bartender at Daniel, and food by Jared Stafford-Hill, previously at Adour Alain Ducasse and, more recently, Maison Premiere in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, which he helped transform from a period-piece oyster-and-absinthe bar to a worthy restaurant.  "}]
drinks: Oysters; black sea bass crudo; bay scallop ceviche; brebis; chèvre; brandade sandwich; chowder-style fluke; beef short rib; brioche with pear confit.

Title: La Vara
Summary: The newest vessel in the small and nimble Spanish armada commanded by Alex Raij and her husband and co-chef, Eder Montero, who also own Txikito and El Quinto Pino in Manhattan.
Review: [{"Review":"APPEARANCES count in food, but great cooking is sometimes hard to spot at first glance. When they arrive at the table, there is nothing prepossessing about the fried artichokes served at La Vara, a four-month-old Spanish restaurant in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. I took one look and thought, O.K., fried artichokes. I know what these are all about."},{"Review":"So what was it that made me want to betray my friends by creating a diversion (Hey, out there on Clinton Street! Is that Martin Amis?) so I could polish them off all by myself? It clearly has something to do with the way all the luxuriously soft qualities of confited artichokes are wrapped inside those crunchy fried leaves and hearts, and just as much to do with that sauce, a creamy aioli with force-multiplying jabs of anchovy."}]
drinks: Moderate considering how full the room gets.

Title: Neerob
Summary: A modest, sunny halal restaurant that serves the fish-friendly cuisine of Bangladesh.
Review: [{"Review":"GOOD Bangladeshi cooking is hard to come by in New York. Though “Bangladesh” is stamped on many menus, too often these are passports to food from other parts of the subcontinent. The longtime touchstone, Spicy Mina, in Woodside, Queens, went dark last year, supplanted by a Nepali spot that also turns out pizza."},{"Review":"One place that lovers of the cuisine have turned to is Parkchester in the Bronx, where Mohammed Rahman owns Neerob. It is on a low-rise stretch of Starling Avenue that is home to numerous Bangladeshi-owned businesses. His modest, sunny establishment serves as a de facto social center, partly for the genial atmosphere — all the customers seem to know Mr. Rahman by his nickname, Khokon — but principally for the food."}]
drinks: Fish dishes, pakoras (vegetable fritters), bhartas (mashed dishes), shandesh (cheese sweetened with date palm sugar).

Title: Arepa Lady
Summary: For more than two decades, Maria Piedad Cano, a.k.a. the Arepa Lady, has parked her cart among the late-night roisterers of Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens. Now her arepas are available at normal waking hours, at a small restaurant.
Review: [{"Review":"It must be a Friday or a Saturday, from April to October, after 10 p.m. — the later the better — and still you may not find her, Maria Piedad Cano, the once and future Arepa Lady of Jackson Heights, Queens."},{"Review":"For more than two decades, she has parked her cart among the late-night roisterers of Roosevelt Avenue. Early in her career as a street vendor (previously, in Colombia, she was a lawyer and a judge), she was canonized in The New York Press by Jim Leff, who later helped found Chowhound. Now 70, she remains his seraphic archetype: a tiny, bright-eyed woman with a halo of reddish hair and the kind of smile typically achieved only after years of solitary meditation, making the quicksilver toss of a $4 corn cake on a griddle a gesture at once elegant and magnanimous."}]
drinks: Arepa de queso; arepa de choclo with chorizo; arepa tela with steak; juices: mango, passion fruit, blackberry and lulo.

Title: Joseph Leonard
Summary: Joseph Leonard may become as adept at feeding its Greenwich Village neighbors as it has been at gauging their taste in décor.
Review: [{"Review":"JOSEPH LEONARD"},{"Review":"170 Waverly Place (Grove Street), Greenwich Village; (646) 429-8383."}]
drinks: null

Title: Blue Smoke
Summary: Since opening in 2002, Blue Smoke has always been a few paces behind the frontrunners of New York barbecue. But when it comes to contemporary Southern cooking, Jean-Paul Bourgeois’s menu is at the head of the pack.
Review: [{"Review":"If you hooked a seismograph to Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group, the readout for most of the last two decades would be boringly predictable. Regular spikes would indicate the orderly arrival of restaurants, with just a few aberrant tremors here and there: the closure of Tabla and, very rarely, a change of chef."},{"Review":"But since the summer of 2013, one quake after another has jolted the needle. The chef of the Dining Room and the Bar Room at the Modern stepped down. Then the same thing happened at the two Blue Smoke locations. Then North End Grill. One at a time, replacements were named. Recently came word that when Untitled moves downtown with the Whitney Museum of American Art, it will get a new chef, too."}]
drinks: Moderate.

Title: HanYang BunSik
Summary: HanYang BunSik's dishes fall under the Korean category of bunsik, or snacks, including blood sausage embedded with sticky rice, kabocha porridge and a skewered hot dog with an airy crust of panko, like a corn dog from the fairy realm.
Review: [{"Review":"Don’t be distracted by the tented stalls outside the 24-hour HanYang Mart in Flushing, Queens, with their promises of baked eggs and potato pancakes shaped like hearts. There will be time for them."},{"Review":"Go in, past the stacks of 15-pound bags of rice and the clothing nook. (If you’ve reached the counter selling deli manjoo, little spongecake fish with guts of sweet cream, you’ve gone too far.) Stop at the sign that says HanYang BunSik in Korean, with an English subtitle: Snack Corner."}]
Recommended-dishes: Soondae (blood sausage); modumjeon (assorted pancakes); hobak juk (kabocha porridge); junbok juk (abalone porridge); budae-jigae (sausage stew); perilla-seed soup with hand-cut noodles; panko-encrusted hot dog.
drinks: $ (inexpensive)

Title: Desnuda
Summary: A romantically lighted sliver of a bar in the East Village serving Nuevo Latino-accented food.
Review: [{"Review":"DESNUDA"},{"Review":" 122 East Seventh Street (First Avenue); (212) 254-3515, desnudany.com."}]
drinks: null

Title: El Toro Blanco
